Great explanation of the theorem. I think a slightly more deterministic (and optimistic) viewpoint here is that when you are looking at the "probability" of something being true, you have to do it with while taking into account the inputs that go in.

So, the probability of someone getting into a car accident doesn't need to be a single number. It can vary based on different factors like if the person is alert while driving, their driving abilities, the conditions of the road, etc. The base probability (which in this case started with 99%) should have those factors in and these should also be calculated while taking the Bayes' theorem into account. Once we do that, we actually can start to see how much our actions (or contributing factors) actually would count towards a different outcome.

The video is great! I think there is a small mistake though. The probability P(HIE) of having the disease while testing positive is not correctly calculated. The reason is that the whole population does not get to do these tests. So, the 0,001 probability of having the disease within the general population (the P(H)) is not correct. The P(H) should be the probability of people having these symptoms to have the disease. So, generally when we are getting tested, there are symptoms that drove us to go get tested, and so we are left within a select group where the P(H) probability of having the disease is actually higher.

To the people who are struggling to understand the example - lets say there are 1000 people out of which 300 people are likely to have disease and 700 people are not likely to have disease. and test results are 80% accurate , i.e 80% correct 20% wrong then we have 4 cases
1) pick a random person from 700 people and test result +ve ( 20%).
2) pick a random person from 700 people and test result -ve ( 80%).
3) pick a random person from 300 people and test result +ve ( 80%).
4) pick a random person from 300 people and test result -ve ( 20%).

Now the probability of picking a person testing +ve(80%) and in the population likely to have disease (300 group) is = probability of case 3 / probablity of case 1 and 3 . because our event is testing +ve and hypothesis is having the disease.

I think the fundamental problem with probability calculation (on a personal level) has to do with the fact that one has to make an initial ASSUMPTION about a possible situation and its possible outcome (it being true or false). Since our assumption of something being true in relation to the number of situations where it might not be true, is based on the irrational premise that something would apply to us, stems from the fact that we often consider things to be (favorably) related to our present situation based on the fact of repeatability and the way we perceive this.
This seems to be hardwired in us through evolution where nature programmed us to have intuition allowing us to make snap decisions to help our survival. In other words, we are programmed to react more favorably to "gut-feeling" than to cold hard calculation (which no one could perform when confronted with an immediate and dire situation requiring sudden action)

This is simplified example because it is not always the case (in fact rarely) that P(e|-h) = 1 - P(e|h). In general P(e|-h) = (P(e) - P(e|h)*P(h))/(1-P(h)). P(e|-h) has to be measured like P(e|h) and not assumed to be 1 - P(e|h). In this case they happen to be the same because he is telling you that has a given. Just fyi to be more transparent and general

theres a fundamental problem. the guy who got the disease and took the test with 99% accuracy and tested positive, he has the disease 100% we know from later. but according to baysian this guy has like 8% chance to have it. so baysian is kinda useless in telling you a definitive reality, its like a statistical minigame which is like nice to know for fun, but if you wanna know if something is real for certain, it is useless. in this case just ignoring the other stuff and just taking into account the 99% accuracy of the test saying you have the disease is all that matters. it feels like the overall lesson of bays is that its good to put information into the right context, and to update probability of things being true, when uncertain, by new evidence. but if you feed it too much irrelevant info, such as the probability of disease in a random population, you feed it garbage, and you get garbage. the issue is for example, i think, that you have alot of reasons to believe you have that disease thats why you got to the doctor and he ordered the 99% accuracy test. you did not account for this into bays equation, because you gave full weight into the info that theres 1% incidence of the disease into a population, but nothing about what it means for only members of population that tick alot of the boxes of symptoms etc. if you fed this info instead you would get vastly different answer. on top of this, generally you seem to give all information equal value in the equation, but it seems to me that some pieces of info are far more valuable that others, which means you need to account for this.

"the test will correctly identify 99% of the people who have the disease
and only incorrectly identify 1% of the people who dont"

from a random sample of 10,000 people, 10 have the disease, and 9990 dont (statistically for 0.1% of the population)

9.9 of the 10 people who have the disease will correctly test positive (99%) = all ten
99.9 of the 9990 people who dont have the disease will incorrectly test positive = 100 people
the remaining 9890 people all correctly test negative

those 100 people who falsely tested positive out of 10,000 people are 1% of the people tested

when you say that 10 sick people tested positive and 100 well people tested positive, that makes it sound like, if you test positive you are 10 times more likely to not have the illness
but that is ignoring the 9,890 well people who ALL TESTED NEGATIVE

if you test positive there is only a 1% chance (out of the 10,000 tested) that you dont have the illness
that is what the test is for

and this is out of randomly selected people
when you show up at the doctors office not feeling well, but with no specific symptoms that flag an underlying cause, you are no longer in the pool of the random population, you are in the pool of people who have SOMETHING wrong with them.

In reality if a doctor sent 10,000 patients to be tested and only 110 came back positive (because there was nothing wrong with 9990 of them) that doctor would quickly be out on the street.

The doctor would not send you out for just one test - they would conduct multiple tests and possibly Xrays, ultra sound, MRI scans... No diagnosis would ever be based on the result of only one test.

If you have the serious illness the symptoms and other complications will quickly follow, and this contrived thought experiment will of had no useful purpose. That is not how the medical profession functions - people are tested for illnesses they are likely to have. If they test positive they are tested again. In the long run the number of people who tested positive are later confirmed when the illness progresses, so the 99% valid and 1% false positive rates ARE the probability that you have the illness.

Nope. The opposite probability of false positives balances\cancels the relevance of arbitrary field statistics to true positives. A field snapshot of 1,000 cases is itself a statistical distortion because it presumes perfect distribution to represent random sampling for the sake of argument, but real test outcome depends on all sorts of conditions outside test parameters. For example, if tests are performed an area where positive results are high, field statistics will simply indicate more positives, say 100 positive results per 1,000 tests, without affecting statistical reliability of the test itself. 99% test accuracy means 99 out of 100 tests will correctly predict the presence of a condition associated with test measurements regardless of an infinite number of variables outside test control including idealized field statistics (location, age, time elapsed after meals, height, weight, sex, political affiliation, med mixing, etc.). The fact that random conditions outside test control affect outcome is reason enough to repeat tests and perform additional narrowing tests.

I was fortunate enough to be invited to the National Youth Science Camp in West Virginia as a Wisconsin delegate in 1989.  One of the staff there explained using something similar to Bayes' theorem, or maybe exactly that, in the study of biology.  One of the guest speakers while we were there presented his alternative theory of how physics worked, and while the camp was excellent, this speaker was not.  I asked how it performed at predicting the results of experiments, and he replied "it's not a mathematical theory".  Dismayed, pointed out that a .1% error in any predicted result would be enough to blow a hole in the standard model (and there were a couple such holes), and asked what he offered for falsification criteria.  He replied "The Standard Model predicts that proton decay will occur, and I say it will not.  If it's observed, my theory is falsified."  I dismissed him and his non-mathematical alternative to the Standard Model as rubbish.

I like what he's saying, but I think some of it is wrong. For example, imagine I am trying to hit a target and I am shooting over my shoulder AWAY from the target. Baysian theory may make me fatalistic and think I will never hit the target. And I think we can agree that "aiming away from a target will never hit the target" so we SHOULD get depressed and give up on that plan, but we should be joyous to try other crazy ideas such as firing TOWARD the target. So I DO think some things are DOA and should be rejected. It's just difficult to know 1) whether your plan was stupid and you need to change plans or B) your plan was good but there aren't any fish in that water, or some other external circumstances that will similarly cause you to fail. Then your "fishing technique" is solid, but your ability to choose a good fishing spot (which is still part of the larger plan) is terrible. So I think we SHOULD give up on SOME things, I think the question is how to know which are efficient to influence and which are not.

Subjective Bayesianism actually does little if anything to change a person’s beliefs. In fact, if the person’s prior probability they assign to their preferred theory is high enough, and the prior probability of the alternative low enough, then it forms confirmation bias in a way that causes even evidence FOR the less preferred theory to be seen as evidence for the preferred theory.
Here’s how:
I set prior probability of theory A—P(A) very high… say at .98. I set prior probability of theory B very low, say 0.02.
Evidence E is now introduced.
The probability of A being true, given E, is:
P(A|E) = P(E|A) x P(A) / P(E)
The probability of B being true, given E, is:
P(B|E) = P(E|A) x P(B) / P(E)
Let’s now say the likelihood of finding E if A is true is roughly 1/10, but if B were true instead, the likelihood of finding E would be 9/10.
How much more likely is it that Theory A is true than Theory B? You might say 90%… but not per Bayesian theory. What’s the ratio of P(A|E) to the much less preferred theory P(B|E)?
[P(E|A)x P(A)] over [P(E|A) x P(A)]. Or [0.1 x 0.98] divided by [0.9 x 0.02] = 5.44. Meaning you would find Theory B to be 5 times more likely to be true than theory A, EVEN IF that piece of evidence is nine times less likely to be found if Theory A were true.
Bayesian analysis, especially subjective Bayesianism, is actually likely what causes cognitive bias. We tend to discount contrary evidence, weighing it much less than evidence that supports our position.

That's more semantics than anything else, you worded it in a misleading fashion. I could tell where you were going but if somebody says the test correctly identifies 99% of people who have the disease and wrongly identifies 1% of people that don't have the disease, unless they were trying to trick me, they would say: 99% of the people who have the disease test positive, and 1% of the people who don't have the disease test positive.

It would have been clear from the get go but with the way it was worded it was unclear whether the % were taken out of the absolute samples, as you clarified later, or out of the group the test identifies because you started with "the test identifies" and therefore people were lead to think subconsciously of the group of people identified by the test and by the time the numbers came it was still the right interpretation because "the test correctly identifies 99% of people" is still in line with the wrong interpretation because it's the correct one up until that point and the switch to the different correct interpretation only happens last second when the thought is already formed by adding "who have the disease", but since the addition of the two concepts match(because those people have the disease), your subconscious tends to use a heuristic and consider the information redundant instead of seeing that the last bit retroactively changes the meaning of the already processed information which then needs to be reinterpreted because you didn't pause, in other words it became an involuntary(or voluntary) bait and switch. To make matters even worse, the subconscious is unable to tell if the pause in itself was due to you pausing or it pausing for an incongruency and by adding the pauses it has on the words you said, it becomes: the test correctly identifies 99% of people, who have the disease, and wrongly identifies 1% of the people, that don't have the disease. Since the addition of commas switches back the right interpretation to the wrong one your subconscious is fucked because the phrase is ambiguous by nature and it cannot be handled heuristically but requires a working memory long enough to not have handled anything until the "and" comes up.

The data is clear, how it was presented was misleading due to the chronological order of the words used as well as the complete sentence with alternative pauses. In other words, your doctor should really take a class on ethics, one on statistics and possibly one on how to communicate them without creating bias, since, as I've shown, when properly worded the statistic is clear to everyone and not in the least bit misleading but when you purposefully word it in a way that is meant to fool not one but two major heuristics used in assessing meaning in speech, what exactly do you expect to happen?

Communication isn't something you can achieve just because you are using language according to convention, you need to factor in working memory and train of thought at the very least, and you tried to fool both, purposefully or otherwise. Reporting the statistics with those words, in that order is reckless at best and purposefully misleading at worst. It's not an "OMG, we are so bad at handling probabilities lol" it's an "OMG, we are so bad at communicating them T.T".

People should really take into account the subconscious processes of others when speaking or misunderstandings pop up around each corner.

That first example is more of a linguistic sleight of hand than it is anything interesting about math. It starts with the awkwardly worded input numbers: "it correctly identifies 99% of the people who have the disease, and incorrectly identifies 1% of the people who do not" (Slightly paraphrasing the syntax, but all of the important words are directly quoted). I guess the first thing to realize here is that "identifies" means that the test shows positive, which is weird, but that does seem to be what the hypothetical doctor means. The next confusing part is that since the numbers are 99% and 1%, which tidily add up to 100%, it's natural to assume, if you're only given a couple of seconds to think about it, that these numbers are for diametrically opposed situations, i.e in a given scenario one thing is true 99% of the time and is false the other 1% of the time. Combining this with the fact that the doctor was asked about what the chances were that the patient actually had the disease and then came back with these numbers, I think it's quite natural to assume that the numbers actually were "99% of the time when you test positive you have it, and the other 1% of the time you don't", which is why 9% seems surprisingly. But actually, that's not what the numbers the doctor gave were. The doctor said that 99% of people that have the disease will test positive, and additionally 1% of the people that do not have it will test positive. Firstly, these numbers are not diametrically opposed, it could conceivably be the case that a test will test positive to 99% of people when they actually have it, and it could still be that 15% of the population without the disease also tests positive. There's no reason those need to add to 100%, but the fact that they do in the example leads you farther toward misunderstanding. The other thing is there's no reason these would be the numbers the doctor would give you, because there absolutely would be statistics available about the number of people who tested positive and then later either turned out to have it or not have it, and those are clearly the numbers you want when you ask that question. Those numbers definitely would add to 100% as the ones in the example do, so it's easy to assume those are the numbers you're given unless you're paying very close attention. If the numbers are given to you in a way that clearly explains which numbers you're getting, then 9% won't seem so surprising to you, because you'd know that you weren't given any information that actually applies directly to your situation, only tangential stuff about the likelihood of getting certain test results when you already know whether or not you have the disease. The patient didn't need Bayes theorem, just a doctor that wasn't jerking them around.

The problem with this is at 2:43 where you state that everyone else is selected "at random". Which is not the reality. Medical tests are never selected at random. Also there's the issue that P(H) is likely based on the positive test results from the test within a population, and therefore P(H) = P(E) in a given population, in which case P(E)s cancel, and you're left with P(H/E) = P(E/H)-----so the probability of the having the disease after testing positive is equal to the probability of of testing positive if you have the disease....basically you're back to the accuracy of the test.

Notable issue with the logic used at 2:33 in that it assumes that 1000 people at random would be tested for the condition without having shown any symptoms. Just having symptoms should increase the probability. To find the actual probability, it should require the information regarding how many people are tested for it and have it come back negative, because you are taking a sample specifically of those tested for it, and a 'random sampling' should be only among those who have been tested. If it's actually that rare, the number of negative tests should still be notable, but the probability of having it should be much higher than the odds of a random person from the general population having it. If even 1 out of 100 people tested had it, that's still a much higher chance.
Of course, a lot of this comes down to the concept of how probability can actually change. Like the odds of flipping a coin 10 times and getting heads every time is like 0.1%, so you could say that 10th flip, provided all previous 9 were heads, is 0.1%, but it's also 50%. (technically, it is 50%, but if it happened it would also fulfill a requirement to reach 0.1% at the same time). And that's an issue with probability in general, it's both an exact and imperfect science at the same time, because there will always be additional variables that will affect the probability that can't be fully accounted for

I didn't say it explicitly in the video, but in my view the Bayesian trap is interpreting events that happen repeatedly as events that happen inevitably. They may be inevitable OR they may simply be the outcome of a series of steps, which likely depend on our behaviour. Yet our expectation of a certain outcome often leads us to behave just as we always have which only ensures that outcome. To escape the Bayesian trap, we must be willing to experiment.

A great video. As you mention at 1:49, getting the prior probability "correct" is the most difficult part of applying Bayes' theorem to practical problems and I would argue you got this number very wrong in the scenario you outlined at the beginning of the video (heance leading to the non-intuitiveness of the result). Our experience with COVID has actually brought the nuances of conditional probability to the manstream, which is an interesting observation given your concluding remarks.

Your hypothetical scenario states that the subject felt sick, and hence why they got tested in the first place. This piece of information is absoultely crucial and MUST be coupled to the Bayesian math. The 0.1% prior probability (that a randomly selected sample from the population has the disease) is only true as a random measurement, i.e., is only true if that sample is truly randomly selected. If the person feels sick (demonstrates symptoms) the chance the prior probability of having the disease increases dramatically. We've learned this from COVID testing and positivity rates. Let's say that demonstrating any kind of sickly symptoms increases the prior from 0.1% to 1%, this changes the posterior probability of having the disease after having tested positive from 9% to 90%--a huge difference in probability (though not quite the 99% that people may intuitively think when first hearing the problem).

Now if the scenario you originally outlined were "You participate in a random medical study aiming to validating the efficacy of a test for a disease that affects 0.1% of the population. Preliminary results for the test show a 99% accuracy rate. You test positive for the disease. Assuming the 99% accuracy rate is correct, what is the probability that you actually have the disease?". In this scenario, the probability is probably much close to 9%.

I feel like this example is all wrong. Just because 1% of all positives is false (1 - P(E|H)), does not mean that 1% of all negative cases will get a positive result (P(E|-H)). Or more relatably: That 1% of all fruit that looks like an apple are really pears, doesnt mean that 1% of all pears look like an apple.

You assume the 99% accuracy of a positive result is true, because you used it for the formula. You also assume that the entire population gets tested because you use the entire population's occurence rate as H. If the entire population gets tested, and the 99% accuracy holds, that means that 0.001 (the occurence rate) is proportional to 99% of all positive tests.

This means the total probability of a positive result is 0.001/0.99 = 0.0010101... .

Which in turn means that the overall probability for a false positive should be (0.001/0.99) - 0.001 = 0.000010101... at the very most.

Please, someone tell me why in the video the

[probability of getting a positive result if you don't have the disease] is equal to (1-[ocurrence rate]) * (false positive rate for positive results) = 0.00999.

If you use 0.00999, then we can throw the P(E|H) = 0.99 thing in the trash because we ignore its consequences and the whole thing falls apart because the real P(E|H) becomes unknown.

If you use 0.000010101... then Bayes puts out 99% anyways and the video only makes a point of how confusing Bayes can be.

The theory can be useful in some "rough calculation" situations, or in providing more value to what seem like obvious solutions but in fact are not.  I like the example of "You run into Tom on the college campus.  Tom is very introverted.  He is either a math PhD student or a business student.  Which is he more likely to be?"  Most people would say "math PhD".  However, Bayes theory might say: "There are ten times more business students than math PhD students, so if there are around 75% introverts in math PhD and only 15% introverts in business, then Tom is twice as likely to be a business student (75 out of 100 math PhDs are introverts, but 150 out of 1000 business students on the same campus are introverts.  150 is double 75, so it is more likely Tom is a business student in this scenario) .  As always, the effectiveness of Bayes is only as good as the quality of the information fed into it.

I am not a mathematician, but in my opinion, the example of the doctor's diagnosis is a bit wrong because it considers that the patient performs the test for no reason. Let me explain, a doctor prescribed this test, so the doctor is performing the first "iteration". If a patient arrives with a set of symptoms that could signify a disease, the probability of the first iteration will be the probability that the doctor, with his experience, will hit the pathology.
Ex: if we are in Wakanda, where the probability of having Covid is 0.001%, but a patient arrives with a fever, dry cough and fatigue, and also says that he was at a party in another country, where there are no sanitary measures, the doctor will ask him to perform a PCR, then the probability of P(H) is not 0.001%, but the probability based on the experience of the doctor to understand the symptoms.

idgi. how is your first example not immediately reducible to the efficacy of the testing? your wording is ambiguous when you're parroting the doctor – "the test will correctly identify 99% of people that have the disease."

a patient only asks a doctor about the likelihood of having a disease before getting a test. once the test is completed, there is a new question, which is: "what is the likelihood that a positive test corresponds to an actual positive case?" this would be the dialogue that comes after a test result.

and if the data shows that "the likelihood of a positive test result corresponding to an actual positive case is 99% in all recorded instances", this would mean that, if you have tested positive, the likelihood of you actually having the disease would be 99%.

so in your example, what you're actually referring to is just a really really terrible test which returns 10 times as many false-positives as true-positives, and therefore has to be verified repeatedly. A single one of the tests would actually only "correctly identify 9% of people that have the disease".

I guess its technically still Bayesian (?) but its a misleading example.

I'm at about 1:00 and decided to figure it out myself. Let's see if I got it right.

So we have 3 different percents

1. 0.1% of people have it
2. The test correctly identifies 99% of positive cases
3. The test incorrectly identifies 1% of negative cases

With such, since 0.1% of people have it, that means 0.099% of people both have it and actually get a positive result.

Then, we have the 99.9% of people who don't have it. If the test incorrectly identifies them as positive 1% of the time, that means 0.999% of people get a false positive.

Since we know the character in this has a positive result, we only need to focus on the positive result cases. 0.099% of the population gets a true positive and 0.999% of the population gets a false positive. This means a total of 1.098% of the population gets a positive result. If we then divide the true positives by total positives and multiply by 100 (since the result is a drcimal) we see that only roughly 9% of positive results actually have it.


Final answer before watching: You have about a 9% chance of having the disease.

~ is different from ~

The problem with Bayes, which I've studied extensively and use every day, is that it can't be applied equally well to all types of data. Essentially, Bayes is an average of an average. The thinking is that the average of the average will weed out all the outliers, but that doesn't work if the datasets that the original average were derived from were faulty. Bayes might work relatively well with diseases that have clear cut outcomes like terminal diseases, but the best example of Bayes NOT working is the 2016 Election. All of the polls that showed Hillary Clinton winning were wrong because their datasets were fundamentally flawed, thus taking an average of them yielded an incorrect result.  Want to know one of the major flaws of COVID policy? Double counting. We were told that we were short tens of thousands of hospital beds and ventilators because we were going to have the regular flu season patients PLUS COVID patients. Do you see the double counting error? COVID patients are often the old frail patients who would have needed that bed or ventilator anyway because they are the ones more likely to get the flu. We were never short ventilators or hospital beds. COVID and flu patients, which are often one and the same, were double counted. Using Bayes for COVID potential morbidity is actually ridiculous because there is no clear cut outcome. Asymptomatic people never get tested because they don't even know they have a disease. People who die WITH COVID are often tabulated as dying FROM COVID. (millions of people die WITH  warts every year, but they don't die FROM the warts). Again,  averaging averages with Bayes is useless if the datasets are faulty to begin with. But... there are a lot of people making a lot of money pushing Bayes and other statistical snake oil on government officials and corporate executives who don't want to admit they have no clue about statistics.

Well, it's a little bit more complicated than that. The manufacturer of the test would ideally have an equal number of positive and negative patients and would apply the same test to all of them. In real life, that's not always the case, which is why the reported sensitivity, specificity etc. values may a little bit off.

If your sample population is highly biased one way or another, just as you assumed in the first 2 minutes of the video, sensitivity (True Positive Rate) and specificity (True Negative Rate) are still relatively reliable statistics. Other interestig statistical values like Positive Predictive Value (PPV) and Negative predictive Value (NPV) exist too, but sadly they can be easily distorted by a biased population, which is exactly what you assumed in this video. If the population is balanced, PPV and NPV can be calculated reliably and they will be exactly the values you would care about the most. They are exactly the values a patient with a specific result would really want to see. However, if you can't trust your PPV and NPV, you can still calculate TPR and TNR and they will be slightly distorted, but still better than nothing.

Anyway, if the manufacturer made their validation tests correctly and used a balanced population, their TPR of 0.99 and FPR of 0.01 mean that their test is really good in every way imaginable.

A side note: "accuracy" is yet another technical term that's related all of the above. It's not the same as TPR or TNR, but it takes into account a all the possible outcomes of a test setup. People often talk about accuracy, but they just don't mean the same thing as statisticians do when they use the term. The Wikipedia article on Sensitivity and specificity has a useful sidebar which will get you started on this topic.

The hospital example is subtly wrong. If the doctor decides that you need to be given the test they already have some reason to suspect that the probability of you having the disease is higher than in general population. So you can't use that as a prior necessarily.

So he says that The Bayesian Trap is our internalization of the Bayes Formula, seeing the same result every time we try something and so becoming certain that another result is impossible. The problem being that we can become certain of impossibility when something is not impossible by the random chance that we have just never yet seen the result happen. Then he says because of that certainty we will continue to do the same thing in the same way, and thus never see a change in result. This is a contradiction.

If one is certain that something they're doing is impossible they would stop doing it, and do something different. Thus potentially having a different result. I thought his beginning argument was leading up to the old adage "you can only succeed if you don't give up," but instead he's saying, "do give up, like you're already doing because this common sense is inherent." I think a better message would be to not inappropriately apply Bayes Formula to the result as a whole, and instead apply it to the result of the specific method being used. In other words when you get to that point of certainty, assume the result is impossible with the method you're using, rather than impossible outright.

The initial probability of 9% only applies if every person in a population is tested - say for example in an universal screening done at birth. But the test is done only to a small subset of the population that is suspected to have the disease (those who go to the doctor and complain about the symptoms). The 1% false positivity rate applies only to those who are tested, and the positivity rate in that particular population must be for sure much higher than in the general population, because there was probable cause to have the test done in the first place. This means the p(H) term is also much higher than the general population incidence (1:1000) and thus the likelihood of a true positive should be much higher than 9%.

The prior likelihood of having the disease wouldn't be dictated by its occurrence in the general population, but the occurrence among people identified by doctors as potential sufferers, in need of testing.

One big correction in the main\initial hypothetical problem: re the final implication (while illustrated by the animation), ca. 02:15 to 03:00 mm:ss, re the odds of the protagonist's 'positive' test result being either 'true' or 'false': The way to find that is not what was explained & illustrated ( i.e., not for her result to be prematurely grouped in with the tiny minority there [10 per 1000] of false 'positives', which would've yielded a 1 per 11 chance of .. something irrelevant ) ; but rather, her odds could be found as the ratio between those false 'positives' and all the 'positives' including hers (all which might total, perhaps, shall we say, +-50 out of 1000?); thus yielding (if the # of false 'positives' were still 10) a 10-per-50 [ =20% ] chance of her 'positive' being false; that is, 40/50 [ =80% ] chance that it's a true result.

This was fun, but it includes an error (that Nate Silver may have made, too, it appears). You said that having someone with a zero prior argue with someone with a 1.0 prior is a waste of time because neither could change the other's mind using Bayes' Theorem. That's not correct. While it is impossible for the posterior to be anything other than zero when the prior is zero (assuming that we don't allow impossible events to occur), it is possible for the posterior to be less than 1.0 when the prior is 1.0. So, while it's hard to impossible to convince someone of something that they "know" isn't true, you can convince someone against something that they "knew" was true.

The reason that Bayesian avoid the above is that walks smack into null hypothesis statistical testing, which, these days, they spend most of their time ranting against.

While I agree with all the points made in this video, after having pointed out how accumulating evidence can change prior beliefs, it would have been worth pointing out that it follows that no fact concerning the real physical work can every be known with complete certainty to be true or false. So long as the initial prior is not 1 or 0, the posterior degree of belief is also not 1 or zero. In a way that overlaps with the last point made, which was that there is no theoretical basis for ever jumping from near certainty to complete certainty - though we do this all the time for important practical reasons. An exception to that rule would arise when the belief concerned the truth of a hitherto unproven mathematical hypothesis for which a new proof or disproof had just been discovered. However, it is usually not that hard to distinguish a statement which is clearly expressed in purely mathematical terms from one which concerns contingent reality.

I remember when I watched this in 2017, something felt weird about this. Your first example, where you say "this test correctly identifies 99% of the people that actually have this disease" you follow it up with "and incorrectly identifies 1% of people who don't have the disease." Those two numbers don't go together. They look like they belong together, since 99 + 1 = 100, but the chance of incorrectly identifying a healthy person isn't intrinsically linked to the misidentification of a sick person. For example, if the test told everyone that took it that they had the disease, it would have a 100% success rate among sick people, but also a 100% false positive rate among healthy people, which adds to 200%. Clearly, those percentages are unrelated to each other. I think this is a bad example, because you hit people with the "99% success rate" up front and you follow it with "so what's the chance that you're actually sick? 99%, right?" but in reality, the 99 is so much less important than the 1% false rate you give right after. That's the information you should be pointing out, not following it up as an afterthought. If the false positive rate is higher than the incidence in the population (which it is, by about 10 times), you're going to get 9% instead of 99%.

This is a really nice explanation, especially as he slides into the second part of the example. But the problem with all these "rare disease" examples (we saw it with HIV and we see it with CoVID) is that people erroneously identify the denominator by assuming the disease is randomly distributed in the population. Why do they do that? Because it actually minimizes the calculated risk for the group under consideration, given that the entire population is the largest number of people possible (and therefore you as an individual are the smallest part of that total). But disease isn't distributed randomly. When we understand risk factors (for example viral transmission during IV drug use in the case of HIV or contact with fomites via surfaces like CoVID) the real denominator is "the set of people exposed to the risk." If you use IV drugs and you calculate your risk of HIV transmission with the general population as your denominator, you're going to come up with a VERY reassuring (and falsely reassuring) number. It's critical to correct application of Bayes' Theorem that we remember in this context that tests are pretty much never ordered in a vacuum. One of the questions he doesn't address here is "what made your doctor order the test in the first place?" And that is pre-test probability.

5:11 There's kind of a fallacy here. You're assuming that that 1% chance of error comes purely from random factors that have nothing to do with you. In reality, the chance that a medical test would be wrong could easily be because of the indirectness of the test. Suppose it's testing for a protein that 1% of people without the diseas have naturally in their bodies, and 99% of people who have the disease have in their bodies. In that case, the probabilities they cited would be valid for a random person on their first test, but you couldn't increase your certainty simply by taking more tests, because all the tests can do is change your certainty that you have that protein. Whether or not you have the disease given the fact that you have the protein is what's actually producing your uncertainty, and the only way to increase/decrease your certainty that you have the disease is to use a totally different test for the disease. Put another way, your probability of testing positive the second time may be dependent on the fact that you tested positive the first time, independently of whether or not you have the disease.

Of course, for a test for a horrible disease, you don't just test the general population at random. If you're getting tested, there's usually a reason, so the odds you have the disease are probably rather higher than the background. Bayes' theorem still applies, but as noted, that probability in the numerator is a bit tricky. I also wonder if the way the results are read isn't different between a wide-spread test where the technician isn't expecting positive results often (because most people won't have it) and when they're testing people who they assume are getting tested for a reason. While some tests have fairly quantifiable metrics for the outcome, often there's a human element of reading the results that can be biased either way.
Similarly, getting two tests done doesn't necessarily yield independent trials. Generally, it doesn't, in fact. That's why a positive HIV test ever will usually disqualify you from giving blood, even if they know you're negative and it was a false result. People who give one false positive are likely to do it again because there's often something in their blood that causes it. Granted, it's also possible for faulty lab technique to be involved or other random factors, but in generally, there's a correlation in the trials.

(Not to say it isn't a good introduction to Bayes' theorem. It's just that people often use this example and everyone I've met glosses over the nuances. I figured this channel has people who are able to handle it, though. :) )

For those interested, the fundamental problem Derek is getting at in this video is the 'monotonicity' of probabilistic logic. Classical logic is monotonic -- that is, once you rule an option out, you can't change your mind about it. Probabilistic (or Bayesian) logic, is essentially an extension of classical logic that allows for a smooth gradient of degrees of belief in a fact (in classical logic, facts are either true, false, or unknown, but in probabilistic logic, you express a degree of belief in a fact as a real number between 0 and 1). Like classical logic, Bayesian logic is also essentially monotonic.

There's one slight error in this video. The second calculation (the probability of having the disease given two positive tests) assumes the independence of the tests. There's a good chance that both positive test results were influenced by the same third variable -- for example, you have a different disease that produces similar symptoms to the one you're testing for, and both tests measure these symptoms. The error in the tests may be correlated or, more generally, have a high degree of 'mutual information'.

Prior probabilities are the source of lots of issues in journalism today. Bayesian formalism of probability is almost certainly the best we have in practical cases. However, people tend to not be able to objectively evaluate and/or accept the results. Since you quoted Nate Silver, I will mention that Silver's last update (November 8, 2016) on 538 gave Hillary Clinton a 71.4% chance of winning the election. Although this gave Trump a better chance than most models, it was still drastically influenced by something other than reality. Most likely, this was some combination of poor polling practices and incorporation of personal wishes into the prior probabilities used by Silver's model. More recently, 538's predictions of the California and Wisconsin special elections were off by a decent amount. Yet, he still seems to maintain his prior belief that there will be a blue wave in the Fall; we'll have to wait and see if he's correct on this one. This does not take away from Bayesian analysis in any way. It does, however, highlight a fallacy in how the formalism is used, especially in contentious fields where people have strong opinions. The posterior of one calculation should become the prior for the next update; it seems that some people don't like that part of the formalism.

There is no actual trap, just mind projection. What I mean by mind projection is that you don’t know the detailed causes therefore you are assuming that there is no actual cause. You are assuming that randomness is an intrinsic property of matter. Good luck proving that!

I especially disagree with Veritasium’s opinion that, “We should probably not have debates between people with 100% prior certainty and 0% prior certainty."
We most definitely should, especially if the alternative action is a breach to human life or property.
I have seen firsthand people change their beliefs even when they have had previously believed for certain that something was true or not true. That’s a part of the human experience, and that’s a part of science!

Probabilities are an expression of belief and an extension of human logic.
There are many ways in acquiring a prior probability; I personally find the Maximum Entropy method enlightening.
Probabilities are most definitely not frequencies, though frequencies influence probabilities.

I even disagree with the way Veritasium presented Bayes Rule.
Every Probability has prior information; the ignorance prior is a theoretical position and does not reflect actual belief. But even if you use ignorance prior, you should include that in your expression. Also, doing Bayes Rule with only two alternative hypotheses is very limiting, it’s no wonder you have very improbable events occur, they aren’t even addressed in your model.
I agree that the prior probability is difficult, but it’s important. With the correct priors, very unlikely events appear to occur out of nowhere.

I highly encourage you and your viewers to read Edwin Jaynes book titled, “Probability: the Logic of Science”. Also look up Aubry Clayton’s lectures on YouTube. He doesn’t quite finish with the Maximum entropy method, but he touches on the more important topics. Then you should do the proofs.

Some people tend to have their minds "blown" by the fact that the conditional probability is "only" 9%. For some other people it's even hard to accept. Usually, though, people feeling sick show symptoms or at least have reasons to go through a battery of tests. We end up believing 9% is an unexpectedly low figure beacause we actually think of it as the probability of having the disease given that you tested positive AND you were sick. It ultimately has a similar effect to testing positive again, since the odds increase.

Two positive tests would only result in a 91% chance in this scenario if they are 100% independent of one another. This was assumed because it is a different test by a different lab. But I think that is an oversimplification. Things that could make them "dependent" on each other could be something like:
1) Administering a test by the same manufacturer (or perhaps the same lab conducts the test even though you went to different doctors)
2) The time you got the test taken was similar (if there is a periodicity effect of your chance of getting a false positive)
3) There is a latent factor about you that makes you more likely to get a false positive.
4) etc

Still fine to use your example, but you should mention that it assumes full independence between the two tests.

The quote you attributed to Nelson Mandela, has a great probability of being incorrect, as there is no recorded instance of Mandela, stating such. There is a much greater probability that Pliny the Elder was the first to give this statement. In his 1855 book, "The Natural History of Pliny" book, he wrote, "How many things are looked upon as quite impossible until they have been actually effected." Of course, while the original statement could have been slightly altered as the book was translated in 1862, both instances were long before Mandela was born. The incorrectness of the author of the quote, reduces the overall presentation.

The scenario you mention in the final paragraphs is exactly what was thrust on the Incan priests by the Spanish: the priests thought their ceremony made the sun rise, so they never ever missed it. It was only after they were prevented by the Spaniards from doing it that they were able to gather evidence that the sun kept rising without their ceremony.

5:12 "...get that test run again, but, let's say, by a different lab, just to be sure that those tests are independent."
I would not expect these two results to necessarily be independent. It's true that the error rate could be entirely due to random factors, in which case the two tests really would be independent. But I would expect that a significant amount of that error rate is due to systematic error. Let's say that the test works by looking for Substance X. Substance X is present in 99% of people who have the disease, but 1% of the population carries a genetic variant that causes them to produce Substance X even when they are healthy. In that case, the test should almost always come out positive for those unusual individuals, no matter how many times you run it.

Bayes Theorem: P( I get a date \ I ask a girl out) = ((P(I ask a girl out \ I get a date)*(P(0.75)))/((P(I get a date))*(P(I ask a girl out \ I get a date))+(P(I don't get a date))*(P(I ask a girl out \ I don't get a date)))
If we say that I ask out 1 in every 20 girls I speak with, then that percentage is 0.05. We assume a 75/25 shot every time I ask. That means that the probability I DON'T get a date is .25 for each ask, and 100% that I don't for each time I do not ask a girl out. If P(E\H) is 0.05*0.75, then P (E\H)=0.0375.
So...
((0.0375)*(0.75)) / ((.75)*(0.0375)+(0.25)*(1)
(0.028)/(0.278)
0.1

Humans mostly have the Priors built genetically and are almost always inseparable. Take the sun example. Now to even observe that the sun rises in a particular way, the priors a common man will have in mind are it's shape, it's color, it's intensity or anything else that separates a stone from making an observation about the sun than to a human. Hi ! there are several things said in this video that are MISLEADING or very INCORRECT. The first reasoning is very very dangerous for the following reason: it encourages patients to believe that if a doctor prescribes them to make a test which fails with 1% probability and if the disease that it tests is rare, then even if the test returns a positive result, you still have low chance to have the disease. This is PLAIN WRONG !! The reasoning is correct if you were chosing somebody at random in the population and subject that person to the test. But if you went and saw a doctor and if the doctor prescribed you the test it actually means that you are not a random person in the population, and that the doctor has some concern that you could actually have that rare disease. In Bayesian terms this means that the posterior probability that the doctor would assign to the possibility that you would have the disease is much higher than in the general population, even though the doctor is not able to give you a number, and that unknown posterior should be the prior that you should use to do the proposed calculation. So you don't have a good measure of your prior and you can't compute a posterior... bad luck !! This means that you should certainly not use the overall probability of that disease in the population and apply the calculation proposed here ! The only thing that you should consider is that if this test is done on 100 people it fails only 1 percent of the time... This video is dangerous because it can lead somebody who goes and get tested for HIV in the US to think that since there is only 0.3% of Americans that have HIV, even if they take a test that has an error chance of 1% there is only 0.99*0.003/(0.99*0.003+0.01*0.997)=0.25 so 25% chance that they have HIV,
but this 25% is wrong, because if you got tested it is probably because you thought you could have been at risk, which already increases a lot the prior probability from 0.3%. Second incorrect point is that Spam filters use what is called the Naive Bayes classifier which is actually not a Bayesian algorithm: like many people who only understand statistics superficially the presenter is confusing "applying Bayes rule" which is an elementary rule from the calculus of probability (no point in calling this a theorem), with being a Bayesian statistician and using Bayesian statistics... Finally, the discussion at the end about the posterior becoming more and more of a certainty as life goes by, this make no sense because this is ignoring that the world is changing, and statisticians are not stupid enough to ignore that. Statisticians actually call this non-stationarity and in that case the statistical procedure are different and "forget some of the past certainties".

You can use bayes's theorem to solve all sorts of things, if you are clever enough to use it the right way. Kind of like the method of Lagrange Multipliers.

A man goes to his physician mentioning that over the past several weeks he has had intermittent bouts of chest pain.  His physicians, says.... better send to you to a cardiologist to undergo an exercise stress test.  "They can tell if this is coronary artery narrowing by the results of the EKG while you are exercising on the treadmill.  They find 'ST depression' during exercise if you have coronary artery disease."  Bayesian theorem applies to this problem.  If the man is a 58 year old hard driving executive, who smokes like a chimney, has a cholesterol of 250, never exercises, has hypertension and father who died of a heart attack at age 45, the EKG is probably not necessary.  (He should go directly to a coronary angiogram).  In this setting, he is so likely to have coronary artery narrowing that even a negative treadmill exercise test is probably a false negative.  On the other hand, if the man is a 26 year old athlete, who never smoked, has stayed trim, has a cholesterol of 135, and a blood pressure of 110/65 and has a no family history of heart attacks, even a "positive" treadmill is likely a false positive. (an angiogram is not necessary).   It is the 48 year old man who is a little out of shape, doesn't smoke but has mildly elevated blood pressure, a cholesterol of 180 and a weak family history (or a similar combination) where a treadmill can help decide if an angiogram is necessary.  This all pertains to people with "atypical" chest pain.  For a convincing history of pressure-like chest pain radiating down the left arm upon strenuous exertion would favor to a greater degree getting an angiogram.    I believe that it is this setting (does this individual with atypical chest pain deserve an exercise stress test or not) is the first recognized setting where Bayesian theorem was applied.  (at least that is how I learned about it in internal medicine residency, long ago).  Very important concept.... and I am afraid that very few physicians understand it.

According to my limited amount of knowledge in psychology, there is a term called "learned helplessness" that could be one of the Bayesian Trap this video describes. It is a self-enhancing process of believing that one is incapable of doing something and failed again and again and again, and that failure fulfills one's image of incapability. The reason of this trap is probably because for every event happening, they are closely correlated with the previous events instead of "independent". So one will become even less willing to try hard or try a different way. The point to avoid or at least become aware of this trap is to reflect on whether I am just inheriting the old belief of incapability from the past failures or I have learned lessons from the past failures so as not to make the same mistakes again. "Independent" means trying things differently and not making the same mistakes again as best as one could.

You are right that the prior probability is the most challenging to assign. That is where your assumption is wrong, too.


The 9% is true only if you assumed the prior probability equal to the frequency of the disease in the general population.
However, this probability is not what you assume before ordering the test.
If a physician assumed the patient has the disease with the same chance as anyone else, there would (apart from general screening) be no reason to test for the disease.

As soon as symptoms trigger a presentation of the patient to a doctor, we are talking about a subpopulation.
When the doctor starts suspecting something on basis of history and clinical examination, the subpopulation is even more specific.

In your case, the correct prior P(H) would not be a background frequency of disease but:
"The frequency of the disease in self-presenting patient population that has been ordered the test." (Had it been possible, the granularity to the degree of symptom set would have been useful, too.)

The posterior probability of getting a second positive test for the disease depends on the mechanism of false positives. In a strictly probabilistic sense, your math seems okay unless a person always gets the same result for the test. Imagine testing the group of 1000 people twice (by two different labs or whatever) and the same 11 people end up with positive results. In that case, the probability of actually having the disease given the positive result doesn't change after the second test.

The problem is "we". If "we" - "I" from yesterday is really independent from today's "I" then after 1000 rejections we can really conclude that "I" am always rejected. We falsely assume that yesterday's result is independent of today's result. But why would that be? If we are still the same? If we change and we we still get rejected, then that might be the law of universe. That we really cannot get a date. That conclusion is only valid if we changed from yesterday's we and we still cannot get a date then there are two possibilities : 1) we think we changed but we did not, 2) we cannot get a date. Absolutely CORRECT.

For a deeper explanation read: "Probability, the Logic of Science" by Edwin Jaynes.

Jaynes makes the point that there is no contradiction when Person A gets one probability of an event and Person B gets a totally different probability. Probability is not something that exists "out there" in reality. Rather it is an estimate made by a person based upon what he knows or believes. Hence, Person A says the probability of event E is 2% while Person B says that the probability s 20%, but they are BOTH CORRECT: Each is giving his personal estimate, and personal opinions can and do differ.

I normally like these videos but this one was off by quite a mile.
The table thought expirement for example, what bayes theorem is for is deriving the likelihood that your model fits your data. Not the probability of a location.
When he is done with the expirement he can tell you the proximal location of the ball with a provided epistemic uncertainty.
Ie, the mean position prediction and the variance 100% comprised of epistemic uncertainty, which is the level of trust he has in his mean prediction.

For relating to this concept ihink it is important to know that variance = aleatoric + epistemic uncertainties.

Aleatoric variance is derived from the error in repeated measurements and epistemic variance is derived from the likelihood of data fitting your posterior.

With warmer colder hints you can update your posterior, the likelihood of a correct model. However this still requires a prior assumption, ie. that the ball is on the table.

Sooooo...I still don’t understand what the “Bayesian trap” is here.

Sincerely, stats PhD researcher who does Bayesian work.

The problem with applying this to Medicine is the quality of evidence. It's estimated that 80% of publications are complete trash in terms of quality of the scientific method. It makes the baseline assumption of the problem a little bit difficult to accept as a valid one. What I mean to ask is: the frequency of .001% was achieved how? Sensibility and Specificity of a test are based on a gold standard, which does not mean that is 100%. It used to be that an autopsy was the gold standard but we've evolved to much more complex diseases including functional diseases that have no anatomical changes measurable. And we actually say that a given population has a frequency of a certain percent based on an analysis of only a part of the whole population, which is usually flawed by itself. So what is the actual number? Who knows? But is a great intellectual exercise.

This is a rather lame comment, but I will put it out there so that you can have a rough idea of what we consider "common" as healthcare professionals.  If a disease occurs in one in every ten thousand individuals, it would be considered a common disease.  I know this sounds like a rather large number to many, but we as healthcare professionals see a large number of patients in a very short time.  Even at small hospitals (anything less than 200-300 beds), we will see a thousand patients very quickly due to the relatively rapid turnover in beds.  Within a very short time, we have seen a thousand cases, and most of us work for decades.  So, things become old hat rather quickly if you learn from your first few encounters and provided that no newer guidance is published.

Well no matter what, if the machine is 99% accurate and you test positive, it's pretty much true that you do have the disease. You can take the 1000 sample size example and give and ideal count of 10 people being identified of having the disease. But if the machine is 99% accurate, then of those 10 people, 99% of them will indeed have the disease, so it's by far most likely that all of them do. What you're doing is saying that 10 people are falsely identified as having the disease after analyzing all 1000 people, then grouping them with an 11th person that does indeed have the disease, which is a bit less than ideal of the machine's track record, though we can let that slide, but then trying to say that the probability is equal to the one person weighed against everyone else that tested positive, rather than everyone else that was tested in total.

But see, this problem states that the machine wouldn't work like this. First you have to test positive, then you look at the machine's accuracy of 99%. If indeed you do test positive, then you can safely assume you have the disease. If you want to reverse the steps instead, then of course most people aren't going to have it. This is what's established in the second part of the problem, but after first laying out that the machine gives you a 99% for having the disease if you test positive. It's more a problem if how this scenario is set up rather than the problem actually being a problem

There seems to be some criticizing of his language starting at the 0:30 mark. In actuality, he didn't error. We can construct a 2x2 probability matrix with actual diagnosis (Y/N) for the rows and predicted diagnosis (Y/N) for the columns. If the test correctly ID's those who have the disease 99% of the time, the top row would be 0.99 (actual = Y, predicted = Y) and then 0.01 (actual = Y, predicted = N). Then he says the test will only incorrectly ID those who don't have the disease 1% of the time. This means the bottom row would be 0.01 (actual = N, predicted = Y) and 0.99 (actual = N, predicted = N). Then we multiply the proportions of the population that actually have the disease through the rows. So, since 0.1% of the population has the disease, the (actual = Y) row, which is the top row, is multiplied by .001. The bottom row is then multiplied by .999 because the sum of the proportions of the rows needs to sum to 1. The result is a 2x2 matrix with a top row of (.00099, .0001) and a bottom row of (.00999, .99001). To find the probability of having the disease (Actual = Y) GIVEN we tested positive (Predicted = Y), we take the value in the (actual = Y, predicted = Y) cell, which is the top-left, and divide it by the sum of the values in the first column where both cases are (predicted = Y). The resulting expression to solve for is .00099 / (.00099 + .00999) = 0.09 (rounded), or 9%.

It seems there is a fundamental problem in this “rare disease” example (which I found recurrent when looking for explanations of the Bayes’ Theorem), that is: OK, you can estimate the rate of the disease occurring in the population, and so, if you were to test EVERYONE in the entire population, you would indeed find that only 0.1% of it has the disease; but to bring this example to the real world: when a doctor asks for such an exam, you would expect that the symptoms kind of match (the probability increases), and you would expect that the doctor had already tested for other more common diseases (probability increases more). So, the point I want to bring is, even though this sickness may appear in 0.1% of the population, the P(H) is not 0.1%, since there is a greater chance that the person has it. I have a resolution for the Bayesian trap at the end. Think of life and effort in terms of waiting for the luggage at the airport. Currently only about 3 incidents occur per 1000 passengers in the US. So the odds your bags are lost are very small. Think of this as equivalent to the odds that if you work hard (even under repeated failures) you will succeed in achieving your goal.
If you do the math, the formula for the probability that your bag is lost after seeing x bags in a flight with n bags is: (3/1000)/(3/1000 + (n-x)/n*(1-3/1000)). For n = 200, after observing 199 bags not yours, the probability that the 200th is yours is still 63%!
Lesson - math is neutral. The message you get out of it depends on what you fit into the algorithm.

Love, love, love your work, Veritasium! I do, however, feel like it's vitally important to point out what I see as a huge flaw in what you presented re: what the second result tells us. It's with respect to the posterior probability if you just went to a different doctor and had them run the same test, and sent it to a different lab (as you mentioned around 5:18).

I only bring this up because this example can create a dangerous false impression that could make people believe they're very, very likely to have the disease just by doing this, when in fact they might instead have very nearly the same 9% chance after doing things like this. People might internalize that idea, and later think they're almost certainly doomed when they're almost certainly NOT. That would be, in my opinion, a very bad misinterpretation to provide, and I'd hope you agree. Less unnecessary panic is better than more. =)

The way the probability updates on later runs would depend to a very great deal on WHY it is that a given test might show a false positive when it is run on someone who comes in and gets a battery of tests run on them, including this one. (Others have pointed out that these are not people selected at random, so that has an effect as well, but I'll ignore that and focus on what I see as the bigger problem.)

For any given test that can produce a false positive, there are usually multiple reasons why that can happen. A common problem is that the test is triggering "positive" on something that is present, but which is NOT the disease being tested for. That sometimes (rarely) happens because of things like cross-contamination or lab execution errors and the like, which is part of with why you'd like to get a second test done. But it can also be that some small fraction of the human population has some other benign marker, often genetic, which just so happens to mimic what was being tested for.

If the person going in initially has one of those markers, they could go to a dozen different doctors using a dozen different labs, and those same tests would likely all come back positive, but using the idea you've presented here, repeated application of that same test would make those updated probabilities converge towards your original P(H), while in reality they never had the disease to begin with. Repeated application of a flawed testing methodology doesn't change the probabilities at all in this case!

Since tests like this can fail in this way, what is much important to do is to apply a DIFFERENT (and often much more expensive) test which can also detect the disease, but doesn't suffer from that same genetic-marker-false-positive flaw as the first one. That makes this sort of test almost fully independent from the first kind of test, and that's when you can update the probabilities in the way you showed.

We see something like this in HIV and AIDS testing. There are a variety of relatively cheap, reliable and fast ELISA tests that are use as initial screening tests. Coming back as positive on the first run of one of those is the sort of thing that people shouldn't misinterpret, which is why they are always run a second time for initial re-checking, and if that repeats, a more expensive and very different sort of test (Western Blot) is run for confirmation.

The important misconception (in my opinion) is treating the test as something that gives a false positive only due to random chance, and therefore just running it again gives you a independent trial from the first one. That's the only situation where it's ever appropriate to re-use the same probability in updates due to repeated trials: when there is no relationship at all between one trial outcome and a second trial outcome. Hopefully I've outlined here just one reason (of several) why that may not be the case in something as vital and stressful as test results where "your life is on the line".

There was a big fallacy here. It was assumed that the two tests were independent.

Suppose, to the contrary, that the result is NOT in the test being done wrong, but in the possibility that the person has some blood chemical that is 99% indicative of the disease.

If the test tests for that chemical is done correctly, then it will be a false positive every time it is run.

Hence, re-testing, in such a case does not change the probability at all.

The key here is the independence of the tests. If they independently are both 99% effective and both are positive, then the figure of 91% is correct. If they are are strongly corellated, as will be the case when a blood marker chemical is measured, then the probability is still only 9% and not 91%.

I think you have incorrectly calculated the probability of the test being positive in the event that the disease is not present (i.e. P(E|-H)).

You have correctly noted that, in this example, since for every 100 people who have the disease 99 actually end up having a positive result, this means that the probability that you will have a positive test if you actually have the disease P(E|H) = 0.99. This outcome is a reflection of the sensitivity of the test, showing that the test is pretty sensitive, i.e. if you have the disease there is a 99% chance the test will be able confirm this. This means you could express that there is 1 in 100 people who actually have the disease who end up having a negative result for this test, so this is what is known as a 'false negative', i.e. the disease is present, however the test did not detect it on this occasion.

However, when calculating the probability of the test result being positive if the disease is not present (part of the the denominator in the expanded version of Bayes' formula, namely P(E|-H)), in this case P(E|-H) is NOT simply 1% or 0.01 as this is a totally different number to 100% minus the 99% (the probability that the test result will be positive if the disease is present).

Thinking about the probability that the test result will be positive even if that person doesn't have the disease reflects something known as a 'false positive', and I believe you have made a basic error by assuming that the false positive (i.e. P(E|-H)) is the same as the false negative (i.e. 1-P(E|H)).

For those saying that the prior probability shouldn't be 1% because we don't normally test random people from the population:

So that's the difference between 'screening' tests and 'diagnostic' tests. In this case, the prior probability is the same as the prevalence of the disease in the population, simply because we're treating the test as a screening one, not diagnostic. If you were to do the test on someone who instead has, for example, symptoms of the disease, then the prior probability of them having the disease is higher, and so you'll come out with a higher post-test probability after performing the test. In this case, the test has been performed for diagnosis, not screening.

This is exactly what the process of clinical diagnosis involves - a doctor first has a suspicion of the person having the disease (symptoms, signs, and risk factors all play a role in this), i.e. their pretest probability of having the disease is now higher than that of the average random person in the population, and so a diagnostic test is ordered to confirm their suspicions. If that comes back positive, then you can be pretty sure they actually have the disease. It's really important that in this kind of scenario doctors don't just order a whole lot of tests in everyone , i.e. those with low pre-test probabilities of many diseases, and hope that something comes back positive, because even if something does come back positive, the chance of that being a false positive is quite high, simply because their pretest probability for that disease was low. Diagnostic tests should be used merely to confirm what the doctor already has a suspicion of - of either someone having a disease (in which case they'd order a SPECIFIC test), or of someone NOT having a disease (in which case they'd order a SENSITIVE test).

On the other hand, the very definition of screening is to identify a disease in people who otherwise would have no indication that they may have the disease, and so their pretest probability is the same as the prevalence of the disease in the population. That's why screening tests are more sensitive than specific - which means that if the result comes back as negative, their pretest probability was low as well and so you can be pretty darn sure they don't have the disease. However, as you can see, if the test comes back positive, the chance that they have the disease is still being quite low (because of the low prevalence in the population), and so that's why screening tests have to be followed up with more specific (but not as sensitive) tests, such as biopsies.

The turkey found that, on his first morning at the turkey farm, he was fed at 9 a.m. Being a good inductivist turkey he did not jump to conclusions. He waited until he collected a large number of observations that he was fed at 9 a.m. and made these observations under a wide range of circumstances, on Wednesdays, on Thursdays, on cold days, on warm days. Each day he added another observation statement to his list. Finally he was satisfied that he had collected a number of observation statements to inductively infer that “I am always fed at 9 a.m.”.
However on the morning of Christmas eve he was not fed but instead had his throat cut.

It doesn’t matter how many cases we list during our inductivist reasoning, nothing guarantees that the next case will lay in this inference we deducted from our observations, as the possible experiments and observations are infinite by number and type.
That's Russell's Inductivist Turkey

I'm a bit late to the party on this one, but I just wanted to say that I've heard the allegory of the man and the many sunrises before and it really struck a chord with me. I thought about it for a while and kept thinking that yeah, as each new days comes, he becomes more and more sure that the sun will continue to rise with each new day. But then eventually, the man will learn one way or another that the sun isn't rising at all, but that he simply is rotating towards it each morning. And just like that, this world that he was only starting to become familiar with and sure of, is something completely different than he first thought. No amount of 'experimentation' (watching the sun rise) could have led him to find this truth without pushing the extent to which he exerimented. And now he's left with a choice: become even more curious about this world as a result of what he's found, or be discouraged by the fact that everything he thought he knew was wrong. Now there are obviously many circumstances that can be related to this story, but my personal favorite is simply how people live. He mentions that people have a sort of Bayesian way of thinking without even realizing it whether it be expecting rejection after many times being rejected, or expecting a low wage at work because that's just how it's always been. And when you think about it, the main thing that separates the pioneers in life from the mediocre is what they choose when their world is turned upside down. Do they choose to accept that they were wrong about the sun rising and start to just dejectedly expect to be wrong, and eventually lose motivation to even try to discover things in the world around them? Or are they motivated by the fact that there's more to learn? Space travel, advances in medicine, hoverboards....none of it could be possible without those pioneers who chose not to give up after a few failures.

Think about Edison. Yeah he might've been a terrible human being who robbed the world of Tesla's genius, but I'm referring more to the whole light bulb thing. "I didn't fail at making a light bulb 200 times, I found 200 ways not to make a light bulb"

Following Bayesian logic, he should've given up after a few failures, and yet he persisted even after 200 and the entire world was changed as after result.

So long story short, don't be follow Bayesian thinking. Don't succumb to the status quo when things aren't working out. Always strive for more, and the world will be better because of it

The prevalence of the disease in the population can be worked out as long as you know the true positive and false positive rates using the following formula:
(Total positives - (false positive rate * sample size))/((true positive rate * sample size) - (false positive rate * sample size))
Before anyone pulls me up on division by zero, I am assuming the tests actually work and it isn't just a random toss of a coin (which is generally frowned upon by doctors). Also, if the test throws out more false positives than true positives, assume the testers are looking at the chart upside down.

this seems like a problem of imprecise language and setup rather then mathematical ignorance:
you stated at 0:30 > "The test will correctly identify 99% of people who have the disease."
In the video you mean this to be equivalent to: "when testing people who have the disease, 99% of the people are identified as having the disease by the test." => P(+|D) = .99
Your statement can easily be misunderstood to : "You have a 99% chance of having the disease when you test positive" =>
P(D|+) = .99
Your following statement > "and only incorrectly identify 1% of people who don't have the disease"
This sentence is misleading because it looks like a restatement of your first data point because you used 1% and 99% when in fact you have given a new piece of information. Also, the use of multiple negations within the statement ("incorrectly" and "don't") make the statement a strange contrapositive. it would have been clearer to state: "the test correctly identifies 99% of the people who don't have the disease" or "for people people who don't have the disease, 99% test negative"
