Just to clear it, as it wasn't explicitly explained. The reason a detector can have 99% accuracy yet if it detects you have the disease and yet only have 9% chance of having it is because the detectors accuracy in terms of false alarms is not accounted for (it detects even when when nothing is there), and so it goes off randomly every now and then which accounts for the 11 people.

Sure it detects correctly 99% of the time. But it didn't factor in the times that it also goes off even when nothing is there. So it's accuracy is compromised by its false alarms

Just my thoughts (regarding 8:10+): Having a prior of 0 on literally anything is a bad idea! We are imperfect human creatures and our most central way of acquiring knowledge is by means of induction, which is also an imperfect method. Having a prior of 0 is essentially claiming that you know with absolute(!) certainty that this event is just fundamentally impossible. Unfortunately, this can be said of few things, if any. In particular, this means that - as you touched on in the video - literally no amount of evidence could change their belief at all! (0 * x = 0) For someone to claim that the hypothesis "my boyfriend is cheating on me" has a prior probability of 0, means: They could catch their boyfriend red-handed and would be JUST as confindent in the hypothesis. It's just unreasonable!

The video gives a figure of 9% (at 2:10 in the video) of actually developing the disease after testing positive to the first test. Does that mean if you have 100 people who have tested positive on the first test, only 9 of them will actually go on to have the disease? Yes, that is the implication of Bayes Theorem, given that there are a much larger number of people (in absolute if not percentage terms) who do not have the disease but still test positive.

And it therefore means that a second independent test using a different mechanism should only get a positive result in about 9% of cases (plus or minus a bit, depending on the accuracy of the second test). This should be made clearer in the video, rather than giving the conclusion if there is a second independent positive test - that is correct but does not give the outcome in the majority of cases.

What are the chances of another positive result if the first test was administered again (given that it would be unusual to have a totally independent second test for the same disease which also has useful accuracy figures). The answer would have to depend on the mechanism of the test: does it rely on factors that could change from one test to the next (change in physiology of the subject, re-interpretation by a different clinician - which would of course make it a separate test if it relied on interpretation and was not an absolute result - or possibly just natural variation)?

The problem of accepting Bayesian statements as "truth" and hence potentially missing out on discoveries is not with the Bayesian theorem itself but how to use it properly. I'm speaking about the fact that the combined probabilities can suddenly look completely different when another feature is being considered (feature == dimension == variable). I would bet that most discoveries in science in the past had a pretty abysmal chance of discovering something new until somebody realized that the application space just wasn't specified wide enough. A good example is Newton's gravity. Applied to big stuff it all was fine, and Bayesian would basically have told a 1900 researcher that there's absolutely nothing wrong with it, based on all the applications until then. But applying it to small stuff created the problems, and the motivation to expand gravity. So, in summary, I'd say Bayesian theorem is pretty useful, but possibly not useful for arguing if there's something to discover, because the definition space or application space will control how certain the outcomes are. Finding those new features that bog down the Bayesian numbers basically then already is a manifestation of a discovery, meaning, something is not as we expect it to be.

I would argue that if you have no prior information, you should set your baseline at p=0.5, which effectively implies nothing other than that a positive or negative is equally likely (which, while often untrue for anything that has a tendency, is useful for approaching a problem as skeptically as possible), and as more information is introduced, you adjust your Bayesian analysis, and depending on which direction the new probability moves (towards p'=0 or towards p'=1), you can make an assumption about tendency, but not certainty, and can assess the strength of that tendency by how far the p' is from p=0.5

Most of the time doctors use a test called ANAs (Anti Nuclear Antibody), the sensibility can range 90 - 99%, the specificity can be also higher than 90% but given that is not very frequent people often get "false positive"(tested positive but you DON'T have the disease).

Is this really not clear?  There are 4 groups, neg who test neg, pos who test neg, pos who test pos (call it PSuccess) and neg who test pos, (call it PFail).  Then, given that P percent of the pop has the disease, the probability that you test positive but don't have the disease is (1 - P) / ((1 - P) * PFail + P * PSuccess) which is close tp 1 if the disease is rare and the test is at the 99% 1% split discussed in the video because the fraction is almost (1 - P) / (1 - P) due to the rarity of the disease.

"The Bayesian Trap" is exactly the same problem as the "Black Swan" problem with induction. Karl Popper had a very good answer to this: The problem only occur when you use induction for finding positive knowledge (how things _are_), not when you use induction for finding negative knowledge (how things _are not_). You can often know with 100% certainty if an idea or theory is wrong, only it is possible to "falsify" them.

Ok, for those people arguing that you increase the likelihood of having a specific disease by showing symptoms;
You are all trying to tackle a question that is very complex, much more so than the video can simply illustrate.

The problem you're all asking is; "how does me recognizing my own symptoms increase the chances of me having the disease?" In response to this, there are three big factors to consider that muddle that question.

a.) People are not very good at telling when they feel sick and in what way. In addition, the presumption here is that the person "doesn't feel 100%," which is a very vague symptom that could easily be contributed to your own mental state. Put simply, people can cause a reverse placebo effect, or that people make mistakes. Felt Symptom =/= Actual Symptom.
b.) Even if this person didn't make a mistake, the other big thing is that almost every symptom can be caused by multiple actual physical problems with your body. This is why, when you try to diagnose your own problems online, you often find yourself self-diagnosing yourself multiple high-risk diseases and problems. Doctors have to sift through all these symptoms to find the most likely one based on current activities, past health issues, and most common health problems.
c.) Finally, if you understand how science works, you might recognize that the "rare disease" they speak of might not even be a real thing. The problem is that, in the community of science, people will label a series of similar occurrences as something, and might even learn enough to put it into a box of a disease. However, later research might reveal the "rare disease" to actually be a facet of a common one, or a combination of a genetic predisposition and another health problem, etc... The idea of multiple personality disorder was once thought to be it's own separate phenomena, but these days it's a form of schizophrenia.

These problems, plus the existence of probably other problems, mean that you can't easily just say that "I felt I had symptoms, therefore it helps confirm the disease". I'm not saying it doesn't help at all, only that the help is so vague and subjective, that trying to treat it as certain(or knowable with doing more research), is not a fair assumption.

But if 1% of false positives is big in comparison to the frequency of the disease (maybe the disease has 0,001% frequency), then this test is worth nothing and you should test again.
With common diseases it may not be worth while to even show the percentage of false positives, but with uncommon ones it should be a requirement.

Yeah, I too think this kind of Bayesianism is ingrained in living things, not only humans, but higher animals too - take "learned helplessness" in dogs, for example; using Bayes' Theorem unconsciously is kinda "hack" that saves time from acting in uncertainty and deciding what to do based on uncertain terms.

So if a dog could not leave cage for 10 times, its posterior probability of escaping will be set to 0.

It's because Bayes' Theorem usually WORKS in nature is that dogs behave like that; but that kind of behavior screws them up actually when they contact with human experiments. That is because human do things that Bayes' Theorem could NOT predict (like, doing the same thing for many many times and then suddenly changing).

So, inherent Bayseianism in people actually hurts them much more in human-to-human interaction, then in human-to-objective_reality interactions...

The a priori probability we have to plug into Bayes formula in the example is not P(you have the disease) but
P(you have the disease|you don't feel fine). Applying Bayes we learn that: P(You have the disease|you don't feel fine) = P(you don't feel fine|you have the disease)P(you have the disease)/P(you don't feel fine).

We need some information about the symptoms: P(you don't feel fine|you have the disease) and the general well-being of the population P(you don't feel fine) to give a meaningful estimation.

Example: suppose that everybody that has the disease does not feel well in general, then you will have to rule out the part of the population that feels well in the dot-diagram model.

Im a doc so this engages me, and I agree with you except for three important things:

firstly if a disease prevalence (percent of population that have the disease at any given time) is 0.1% then it is more common than the accepted definition of a "very rare disease" (which is the term you use at 0:21). Its not even inside the def. of a rare disease (1/1500).

secondly and more importantly, if a doc tested for a disease that has a 0.1% prevalence, he already had a clinical suspicion because of symptoms and/or other tests, meaning that the starting probability is much higher than 0.1%. An exact number is almost impossible to get to in real life, however the theoretical possibility will be the number of patients that have the disease when that doctor gets suspicious enough to test for it, thus the end probability after one and two tests will be much higher than the disease prevalence which is the number you used,

thirdly the way you present inverse specificity is wrong. You define it as identifying a certain amount of the population who do not have a disease. If this was true then specificity would be dependant on the number of people that dont have the disease. A silly idea. No. Specificity is the chance that those who do not have the disease but are tested for it are correctly identified as not having it (and the inverse sensitivity will be the chance that a person who is tested and does not have the disease gets a false positive).

I think there is an easier way to see Bayes' Theorem. See what you think:

P(A AND B) = P(A|B)*P(B) = P(B|A)*P(A) (Since "AND" is symmetric it's clear that both are equivalent.)
=> P(A|B) = (P(B|A)*P(A))/P(B)

problem with this example is, that the patient has symptoms. it is therefore not a good idea to apply the overall frequency of the whole population, because this is not comparable to the patient in the example. it would be smarter to apply the frequency of the rare disease in a population in which everybody shows the same symptoms as the one patient in the example. not comparing sick patients with healthy people in this way  drastically increases the validity of the test. in medicine,  this is called "preanalytics" .

The Bayesian analogy [of the man coming out of the cave to witness the sunrise for the first time] can be extended to illustrate the trap. After the man witnessing the sunrise and set for 20 years, the man feels certain that the sun is predictable. Then, one day, it unexpectedly goes supernova and explodes, which would rather surprise the man for a nanosecond. The trap was that the man was too confident in his understanding of the sun because of years of observation that reinforced his confidence. Bayesian logic is useful, but please keep in the back of your mind that we do not know everything about the universe, even though our predictive models are quite good. There's always a first time for everything. On the other hand, however there is still no reason to believe in things for which there is no evidence, just because they are not _impossible_.

There was a psychiatrist (his name escapes me) who wrote a book called "Knots," and in it he posited that there were various ways in which people thought they "knew" something.
The 3 relevant categories imo, were:
If you know that you know - then you know.
If you know that you don't know - then you don't know.
But ... If you don't know that you don't know - then you think you know!
And that seems to track with Bayes Theorem, where people assume they know something without all the data or without sufficient understanding of the variables.

The false positive chance was given as 1%. That was one of the premises. The chance of having the disease is therefore (roughly) 99%. If it's actually 9%, then the false positive rate on the test must be 81%.

In the real world, this discrepancy would be due to the fact that not everyone in the entire population gets tested for the disease. Only people with symptoms would get tested, which would lead to the very good accuracy of the test. So yeah, if you had no symptoms and randomly decided to get tested for that disease one day, then you might skew the results.

Oh yes, I've been thinking about the validity of propositions. Looking at it from different perspectives like foundationalism and coherentism. You must be familiar with the Cartesian Argument which takes you to the statement "I think therefore I am" and it is the 'methodic doubt' which takes you there. So, I thought why not doubt 'Logic' itself? Descartes didn't doubt logic he said there are certain 'simple' (not composites) things which cannot be doubted like shape, quantity etc. But according to the Münchhausen trilemma they can be 'doubted' as well. So why not doubt 'Logic' itself? Say we doubt it, the moment we apply the methodic doubt, we cannot make any deduction whatsoever. Since, making any deduction requires certain laws of logic to be true. In fact the method of doubt itself is logical. So, there are certain things which cannot be doubted. Like, Mathematical Logic; if you wish to draw any judgement whatsoever. So what you said about having either 100% or 0% belief is quite correct epistemologically. I wonder why this method of epistemology is not widely accepted and talked about.

The second, philosophical part is a bit misleading - your prior expectation of something you have not seen yet is not zero. Zero prior means you have direct evidence or some kind of a conclusion of it being impossible. That's not the same as being agnostic about it, if you are agnostic about some aspect of life, your prior expectations in that regard are spread our more or less evenly, each scenario having a similarly low value, but not 'zero'.

Wouldn't the probability of you having the disease after two successful tests be:
(1 - (1 - 0.09)(1 - 0.09))?

Proof: Let P(A) be the probability of the first test correctly predicting that you have the disease and P(B) be the probability of the second test correctly predicting that you have the disease. Let P(C) be the probability of you actually having the disease. Notice that P(~C) is the probability of both tests incorrectly predicting that you have the disease. Therefore: P(~C) = P(~A)P(~B), from which it follows that P(C) = (1 - P(~C)) = (1 - P(~A)(P~B)) = (1 - (1 - P(A))(1 - P(B))). Given P(A) = P(B) = 0.09, P(C) = (1 - (1 - 0.09)(1 - 0.09)). This Evaluates to 0.1719, which is very different from 0.91.

I prefer to think in terms of sets. When you say P(H|E), I say P(H∩E)/P(E). These primitives are easier to grasp and manipulate. The intersection is where the magic really happens. Whenever an intersection pops up, ideally you'd get data on all of the interactions between sets. It tends to get too unwieldy for less trivial examples, but you should at least be cautious if you proceed as though they're uncorrelated. For example, if the false positive rate is based on the general population but you take the test because there's already a suspicion, you're probably more likely to be ill. Similarly, a second seemingly independent test might be more correlated with the first test than the disease, inflating the probability if you're naïve. That's also a kind of Bayesian trap no matter which way you go: filling in gaps for information you don't have or getting bogged down trying to get it because you need so much.

You went to the rabbit hole. you looked into it. "Yep, it's dark. Too scary. I'll just make a video about how it's dark."

Nope. I come out of the rabbit hole after in free fall for about two years and drag in you with me:

1. non-informative priors are a thing, but one still must choose it. This introduces an element of subjectivity into the methodology. Any and all science based on Bayesian methodology is inherently subjective. That doesn't mean it's useless; it's clearly useful. I'm just pointing out a scientist's worst nightmare: your work is subjective.

2. Assuming you know the correlations between all probabilities, one of three things will occur by adding in new information: the probability will instantly become 0 (contradiction), not change (irrelevant information), or increase. However, in the absence of knowledge (i.e. in reality), you don't know the correlations. Hence, it is completely logical and consistent to say that the probability of a given person dying in a car crash is 10^-4 while maintaining that the probability that you die in a car crash as being 10^-18. This is because you don't know anything about a given person but you know a lot about you.

3. Conditional probabilities are based on perspective and knowledge. The more you know, the more you account for. We all know something. There is no such thing as a true marginal probability.

4. You are in fact wrong in your assertion about the dogmatic person's argument. If the probability of A given I is 1 but Ac is true, then the probability of A given I and Ac is 0. Thus, one must either conclude that the initial condition was incorrect or that Ac is in fact false. But this is irrelevant because debates are adversarial systems of arguments. If you're trying to convince your opponent, you're doing it wrong or you're not debating. The whole point of a debate is to convince the third party who is watching that you are right. With this information, the third party can then look at the information to determine the correct course of action.

5. There is a murder. Three suspects are apprehended at the scene but only one set of prints is on the murder weapon. The prosecution shows that the probability that the suspect on trial's prints are on the weapon given that the prints match is statistically significant (i.e. he is the murderer). The defense shows that because there were three individuals, the probability of a match for at least one of the suspects given that three were present is not statistically significant (i.e. reasonable doubt is present). This example illustrates the importance of prior distributions.

6. The test itself is a conditional probability; an expanded form would be "what is the probability I have the disease given that I have a positive test result and the test result was done with such and such methodology and the initial framework study was based on so-and-so methodology?" From your perspective in life, you can come to a vastly different estimate that is in fact logically consistent simply because of your subjective reality.

7. The Butterfly Effect is a great example not because of Russel's Teapot but because it's not necessarily irrelevant, and you can't prove it one way or the other because you can't test for causation.

I don't think you need to understand Bayesian statistics to conclude that, if doing the same thing over and over is producing the same results, then you should change what you're doing. That seems pretty obvious to me.

8:20 Regarding "if you have no instances of something, it will seem completely impossible" - I'm pretty sure that is a frequentist method of estimating your prior. and frequentism is in some sense is the main competitor to Bayesian inference, so it's not surprising that would lead to problems. The correct Bayesian "I dunno" starting point is to use an estimate that would convey the least possible information content (aka an estimate that has minimum entropy), which in this case would be 50-50.

(But the bigger point still stands, in that if you keep observing only one outcome and not the other, you'll still end up with an estimate towards certainty. So I'd agree about experimentation. My hypothesis is that, too often, people just keep rehashing and re-referencing the same events and arguments, instead of trying to find new or stronger ones. The repetitions keep "updating" our certainty, even though we've already taken them into account.)

One problem with the medical example is that the tests are not universally applied to blocks of 1000 people. It's only applied to those are exhibiting the proper symptoms. For a doctor to tell you they think you have the disease, you'll have to match the symptoms and test results. This also doesn't take into account false negatives or the fundamental working processes of such tests. Somebody could not have the disease but have some biological factor giving consistent positives or vice versa. It's not just that a test might be 10% accurate, but the biological reasons why.

Commenters point out that the the base probability is not 0.001 because you had vague symptoms. Technically correct, but the assumption that reported vague symptoms correlate positively with the disease is questionable. The correlation may be as good as random, or even negative. For example if mostly crybabies report vague symptoms but only tough globe-trotting guys like you get the disease.

At 5:55 you make a dangerous error by assuming that false test results correlate with nothing (it's a random chance every time you test) or they correlate with the methods and people of the lab. Generally that's not true. If they were random the lab would repeat the test until they got acceptable confidence. Random or systematically bad test execution are sources of error worth eliminating, but the quoted sensitivity and specificity mostly correlate with the patient and their disease state. That's why testing is a hard problem.

Every person and thus every patient is different, physiologically, biochemically, etc. and everyone's disease state at the time of the exam is different. The test will give you a true or false reading depending on where you are on these variables. So the way to know if you specifically, right now, have the disease is to ask different questions. If your first piece of evidence is biochemical, get some imaging evidence. If the disease tends to involve both the nervous system and metabolism, test the other system. If you're investigating disease X, consider also diseases Y and Z as alternative explanations for your findings. Doctors do all this.

Probability is hard, and so is medicine.

Wow, good philosophical wrap up!

I think it's important for anyone who wants to intellectual to reinforce the certainty of uncertainty. I love a good discussion and prefer discussions with people smarter than I am. Unfortunately, it seems to me we have an fairly large culture of people asserting absolutes where absolutes can't be known. As an amateur, this is infuriating. Intellectual honesty is what an intellectual builds their integrity and social capital on. It's no wonder there's such a large percentage of people skeptical of intellectualism and science. You don't need a formal education in statistics and logic to intuit an irrational conclusion. A skeptic who doesn't understand enough to reason why they're skeptical is likely not going to be meek enough to engage in a discussion with most people, but especially anyone who's going to go as far as to criticize or stereotype a persons intellectual character based on the subject matter their skepticism which is just as abusive and wrong as any other form of bigotry.

So to encourage rational thinking and a pro-science mindset, let's stop asserting higher certainty than what the data represents, stop criticizing those with a different understanding even when it's obvious it's based on ignorance or irrational thinking. I think that just makes it worse. The appropriate thing I think is to be honest about what the data represents, recognize when we don't know things and not pretend we're absolutely sure, and really, really, REALLY, encourage people to ask questions, even (possibly especially) absurd questions.

EDIT: If you don't know anything about philosophy, and are just here to troll, please don't bother commenting. Your need to lash out and insult philosophy because you don't understand it just demonstrates your own intellectual insecurities.

This guy seems like more of a mathematician than a philosopher. If he knew the fundamentals of philosophy, then he wouldn't have floundered for so long on the the subject of first principles. I don't really blame the guy. It's not exactly something that most people know about, but it's sad that other people with more knowledge on this topic have discussed it more thoroughly on YouTube and yet this, one of the less thorough and complete iterations, is the one that ends up trending.

I get that some of the best and most useful explanations of the application of Bayesian theory on YouTube are also some of the most dense and least accessible for the general viewing public, but I'm not convinced that exposing more people to a watered-down version is really helpful or even safe. Giving people access to big ideas without delineating their full contexts is an invitation for their misapplication and misuse on a large scale. Furthermore, it's too easy for content creators like the host of this video to insert their own biases into a video like this when they don't fully understand the topic and they're under pressure to create a cohesive video about it. Some of the viewers may have benefited from seeing this video, but I'm just not sure whether the pros outweigh the cons in this case.

Sorry but your first calculation is totally wrong because it is based on a logical fallacy. You assume that a random person of the population would be tested. In reality what you want is something like the frequency of the disease in the population that has a reason to get tested. For example those having a certain symptom. I don't know about you but I don't go and get tested about random diseases just for the fun of it.

Lets make some calculations. Lets say that fever, neck stiffness, and a change in mental status is a sign of meningitis 60% of the time i.e. more than 1 out of 2 that present this symptom actually have meningitis and those are the people that are going to be tested so P(H) = 0.5. and lets assume that your test accuracy is the same as in your example. Then

P(H|E) = (0.99 * 0.6)/(0.6 * 0.99 + 0.4 * 0.01) = 0.99331103678 and this is a lot more realistic.

Now If a random person from the population was tested then what you said would be true but that is not the case here. To be honest for the first time I don't like how you present something because this can give a false reassurance to someone that it shouldn't.

At one moment you talk about the pointlessness of a debate between two people who believe an event is 100% likely and another who thinks it 0% likely. You say that they will never be convinced of the other's viewpoint, but this is not true. A correct statement would be that will ALMOST never be convinced by the other's viewpoint.

Suppose a random real number, x, is chosen from a uniform distribution on [0,1] and somebody tells me that a "Nice number" is a rational number greater than one half. They then ask me what the probability that x is nice. I correctly tell them it's zero. they stubbornly tell me it's 100%. An independent third party looks at the number and tell us each that it is rational. To renew my estimate with Bayes' Theorem I get the unhelpful 0/0, however I can in reality revise my estimate to 50%. If we inspect the number and it is 2/3, I can now say that it is 100%, and I've been brought around to my opponent's side of the debate, however irrational he was to be on that side to begin with.

No. Your hypothesis is wrong. We are not 'too Bayesian'; we are not Bayesian enough. Either our models are not detailed enough, or we take mental shortcuts, such as your example of treating frequent occurrences as having 100% probability. Bayes' Theorem never gets you from uncertainty to certainty. That's just our brains making a mental shortcut, which is false/invalid, aka a fallacy. The moral of the story: When your intuitions lead you to think Bayes' Theorem is wrong, the most likely scenario a priori is that it's actually your intuitions that are wrong, and that you should become more Bayesian, not less.

I have an interesting experience that I didn't know until today related to Bayes' theorem. In Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) part of your therapy is to combat negative predictions.

"I don't want to go bowling with friends because I'll suck at bowling and gutter it every time and they'll all laugh at me, and I'll have a panic attack."

When you think of this logically, you can reassure yourself: "Well, you could put the barriers up if you want, but you don't know you'll be awful at bowling, and there's nothing to suggest your friends will laugh at you for playing badly, and that you'll take it badly yourself."

In theory, when you can reassure yourself by thinking through with logic and dispel negative predictions you can do the activity, and discover that it's not so bad. And the next time you do it it's fun again, until you really have no problems going bowling with friends.

Your prior predictions are wired to the point of depression and anxiety through some previous events. CBT encourages you to let the world run a bit more to give your brain the data it needs to realise things aren't that bad. A few more iterations of Bayes down the line and your predictions are back to normal.

Now, my story differs when (while the activity wasn't bowling) I was able to overcome fear and negative predictions... only for those predictions to be confirmed. I got unlucky, maybe, but then I tried again with similar results. Unlucky again?

Unfortunately for me, CBT has had the opposite effect, and made it harder for me to trust that I am capable of a "normal" life. But this video has definitely given me insight into how my brain is working out its worries. And maybe even if the sun hasn't risen for me twice in a row it has just been terrible luck... but every day I don't go outside to look I miss the opportunity to see it rise.

By the way Derek, with respect to your medical test analogy, the application of Baye's theorem to the second test is not without complications. Most of the time in the medical field, a false positive is not completely based on chance, but rather, the presence or absence of physiologic variations that trigger a positive test result in the absence of the disease in question. So regardless of whether or not a patient has a disease, a second test measuring the same biologic marker, phenomena, etc. will more likely than not yield the same result, as the thing being measured likely does not fluctuate much (for if it did fluctuate a lot, it would not be used by the medical field as a test for anything, as it would be too unreliable). The only time you could apply Baye's theorem to a second test in a medical context would be if you used a different test for the disease that measured a completely different pathway or in a totally different manner from the first test.

The second test is probably not truly probabilistically independent from the first test since they likely use similar methods and the false positive might have been caused by some other factor or event. Most people probably won't see that, and you probably considered that, but this is important to note.

Something I was kind of hoping he would mention is that there is another factor that makes it even more unlikely that you would have the disease, namely that they did "a whole battery of tests" and you tested positive for one. if each test had a 1% rate of false positives and they did 100 tests then there is a ~63% (1-0.99^100) chance that one test would produce a false positive, meaning that it is actually probable that the doctor would diagnose you with something, although you were in fact fine. This combined with what was discussed in the video is why it is a bad idea to do excessive amounts of tests for rare diseases on people with no good prior reason to suspect they have the disease.

In the "get a second lab test" example, it actually gets a lot more complicated, because the way you calculated it assumes that the probabilities of a false positive on each test are independent. In reality, there are a lot of ways that this can be false. For example, they might be testing for a specific antibody, and the presence of that antibody itself may be an unreliable indicator. In that case, you would likely get a positive test result every time you ran the test, regardless of whether or not you actually had the disease.

Note that we are assuming that re-running the test has the same chance of getting a false positive.

For example, perhaps the 1% of false positives are due to a presence of antibodies that look identical to what is being testing for. Those antibodies will register every time, and you'll learn nothing from re-running the test. If the lab has a 1% change of mishandling a sample, then re-running the test is helpful.

If both you and your doctor thought you needed to be tested for such a rare disease to begin with, that in itself is evidence for the disease that you didn't account for in that 9% result.

Also, running the same test with a different lab doesn't necessarily constitute new evidence; it depends on what that error rate represents. Say the test reliably tests for the presence of some chemical in your blood, but that the chemical doesn't always mean disease. Then, detecting the chemical over and over again with the same sort of test isn't going to affect the probability that the presence of the chemical means disease. On the other hand, if the margin of error represents false positives for the presence of the chemical, it might change the probability estimate.

Statistics are voodoo math. The problem with your initial example is that the accuracy of the reliability of the test is pretty questionable. If you assume it is correct, and you assume that your definition of its accuracy is correct, then you're probably assuming too much. Does the reliability of the test include the Bayesian factor already? How do they determine that reliability?

And, as in all statistics, as you learn more about the particular facts of the case, then you can get a better understanding of the "chances" of an occurrence. But the real chance is either 100% or 0%, because you either have the disease or you don't. Statistics is trying to gain knowledge of something without knowing all the data. The test may have an accuracy rate, but there is a truth. The disease is in your body or it isn't, and whatever number you assign to the probability of your having the disease doesn't change whether you have the disease.

Statistics are useful for planning purposes, but you should never mistake statistics for facts.

Of course we're not the first group to say this, and certainly not the most profound use of the philosophy. I feel like that phrase is the antithesis of Bayes' theory. I read about this in Drunkard's Walk.
One thing that blew me away was the number of doctor's who incorrectly answer the following question
A disease has two symptoms, one common, one rare. Symptom A is suffered by 99% of the people with the disease and symptom B is suffered by 1% of the people with the disease.
Is there a greater probability that a person will present with symptom A and B, or with B alone?
Most people say that a person is more likely to present with both symptoms rather than just B, but this isn't correct.
99% will present with symptom A. Of those 99% only 1% of that number will also present with B, but 98% will present with A only. So if you have 10000 people, 9999 of them will have symptom A and of those 9999, 99 will also have symptom B, but 100 of them will present with ONLY B.
If this disease is 100% fatal without correct treatment and 100% survivable with correct treatment, 100 people will die because the will not correctly diagnose them, because they fail to present symptom A.

In a non-personal perspective, this is actually a good justification for fields like theoretical physics, where the phenomena sought can only be seen through evidence because they exist at such a small scale that they're vastly beneath our perception. That's not to say it confirms anything in those theory-focused fields (its those fields' jobs to confirm their own theories), but it does serve as an interesting philosophical basis for the pursuit of the unseen. In a way, the theoretical fields are us speculating about phenomena then deciding what that evidence for those phenomena looks like (or, speculating about phenomena that other phenomena is evidence for, then deciding what other evidence would prove the speculated phenomena). The "Bayesian trap" is an ironically logical way to argue against theorizing about what we have zero evidence for. Being aware of the "trap" is a reminder that it's indeed worth speculating about what we cannot observe directly, and that what we observe directly isn't necessarily all that exists.

This kind of justifies spiritualism and some pseudo-science as well depending on your interpretation, and at that point I have to remind that this is just a justification for speculation, not a suggestion about proof or soundness.

CORRECTION: (for the disease test example): this is true only if the false positive are due to true randomness. The fact is that you can have a false positive due to an unknown factor. For example, the test can interact with a medication you are taking for something else and give you a positive, the test can interact with a protein in your blood that only a certain % of the population has, the test can interact with an other disease that you have miking it a false positive to the desease you are looking to test. Many other reason are possible.

Let say that out of 1000 people, 10 have a mutation that produce protein Z in their blood, and 1 person out of 1000 has the rare desease (that only 0.1% of the pop has).
Let say the test again, as in his example, is 99% positive if you have the desease and will have 1% false positive.
What you don't know is that the false positive is due to the interaction between protein Z and the test.

So if the test is positive (which it will be for 11 out of 1000) TWICE, does it mean you have 91% chance of really suffering from the desease? NO it doesnt. Because it will always be positive for those SAME 11 persons.

The fact is that medical test, mostly for complicated compounds, are never 100% correct. In part because of some randomness, and in part because of some known and unknown factor. Even if you have 2 different test, some of the unknown factor afffecting the test can crossover the twos.

The assumption that the 2nd test is independent of the 1st is flawed - not in the colloquial sense, but statistically independent - i.e. you can't learn anything about the outcome of one by knowing the outcome of the other. But they're correlated via the variable "having the disease"*, and thus you wouldn't update as much b/c you already expected the 2nd test to come up positive a bit more.
Keep making that assumption, one might call you a rather ... Naive Bayesian. B]

*(and maybe others depending on whether the test results for a particular sample are actually fixed instead of varying randomly - maybe boh tests ultimately measure with perfect accuracy whether there is a molecule produced by a tumor, but 10% of the population just produce it naturally b/c of genetics.)

99% != 91% because "the reported accuracy of the test" is not the correct description for the 99% parameter which is merely the accuracy to identify a positive among positives. A better way to describe test's accuracy is to just outright say the false positive and false negative rates. At least then there is a chance people won't jump to conclusions. Even better is to describe the test in terms of the population (most likely prior probability) thus: "this test identifies positives from the general population with a 9% probability".

The interesting thing about Bayes' Rule is that assumptions are explicit. They're not implicit and hidden (such as randomness and equality of trials). We're often hit with "considered accurate to within 3%, 19 times out of 20". We usually round that off to certainty. However, in that 20th time, there might be a gamma ray burst from space. Our assumptions would doom us.

We use Bayes' Theorem automatically, unconsciously. It is the normal state. It is, in its bare bones, learning by repetition. The prior probability changes with each iteration -- as more evidence accumulates. We do that in the courtroom to determine what probably happened. We do that when judging groups.*
Read the following out loud, twice.
"When an idea is repeated multiple times it is reinforced in the brain."

And Mother Nature seems to use the version of it that works for multiple competing hypotheses. Using Feynman's QED we go back in time from a photon's detection and find that if we pretend it took all paths weighted by probability then it matches reality. And, of course, given a photon leaving an electron we and Mother Nature know the future only to a degree of probability. Even astonishingly rare events can happen. If it can probably happen even only once in the lifetime of a universe, it could happen tomorrow.

Science is in the business of finding out what cannot be. The "not" operator drives evolution, too. I can almost dismiss a man's claim of a motor that harnesses the Earth's magnetic field to drive a scooter because of prior experiment. And yet a demonstration would be new evidence sufficient to change my mind. A mind that can be changed is necessary to do science. ("That's funny. It isn't what I expected." begins many a great discovery.)
__
* It is the source of religious prejudice, racial prejudice, nationality prejudice, language prejudice, looks prejudice, age prejudice, and more. All prejudgment should be based on prior experience with that group. But it is only the prior. The prejudgment must be open to being modified by new evidence. How much to modify your likelihood of having the disease based on the second test would depend on whether there is correlation (and what the cause if any of that correlation might be) between the false positives.

If false positives occur due to faults in the application of the test, the distribution ought to be random, so simply taking the test again would make you more confident of your probabilities.

But, if false positives from a specific test occur by detecting some other thing that is part of the person being tested, then you need to take a different type of test, not just the same one at a different doctor or lab.

Most real-world tests probably has a combination of both randomness and order to their results, so just to be sure, take a different test the second time.

On the second run of Bayes Theorem, you need to know the likely hood that a false positive (and also a false negative) will again produce a false result in successive tests. Since these tests may not be independent just by using different doctors and facilities.

For instance, if the 1% get a false positive because that 1% has some gene which produces some protein which causes the test to always return positive. Then you should expect that once you get 1 false positive all successive tests will also be a false positive.

Basically in the second run of the equations, factors may effect P(E | H) and P(E | -H). It is an important distinction to make as people have actually gone to jail because some statistician didn't track those changes and testified that an Event was completely improbable and in reality was extremely likely.

Several times in my career I've had to pull "signal" from the noise of "new physics" sensors. Such sensors often have "events" that may or may not indicate a detection. When there are lots of events, simple statistics serves well to establish the SNR and report the most likely signal value.

But what about when detection events are few and far between? How do we separate the signal events from the noise events? The answer is we don't try: We instead try to estimate the signal from low-rate statistics. And that means using a Baysean approach, which is precisely what the Kalman filter can do (when used properly).

5:10 in the example given of having the test repeated, there is an assumption that the false positives are random events and have no connection to something special about the person undergoing the test, i.e. that having had one false positive result then the chance of a further false positive at the second test remains the same 1%. In the real world there may be some unknown factor that is making the test more likely to give an incorrect false positive. So if the test unbeknown to the doctors and the lab technicians is affected by taking an anti-inflammatory pain killer, then a patient who does not have the disease but is taking routinely ibuprofen for their back pain may be more likely to have repeated false positive results. Of course if we knew of this confounding factor then we could use different specificity and odds ratios relevant to a specific demographic of people undergoing the test. As a silly example: urine pregnancy kits have a certain accuracy of detecting pregnancies in sexually active women, but it is obvious that all positive results for those who are celibate are false positives as well as any samples from men that the lab technician might wrongly undertaken the wrong test kit upon.

99% of the tested people from group (b) end up with a positive = c
1% of the tested people from group (b) end up with a false positive = d
a = 100,000
b = 100
c = 99
d = 1

Out of every 100,000, 1 person is tested positive but doesn't actually have the disease.

There's a problem with this example as it pertains to a medical diagnosis. True, if we randomly sampled 1000 people, what he says would obtain, however, when someone goes to the doctor, they are not part of a random sampling. They are typically non-random, self-selected person that is already exhibiting symptoms. This is additional information that forces a reformulation of the probability they have the disease if the test is positive along the lines of: the probability that you have the disease if you are already exhibiting symptoms and have tested positive for the disease is X. This is going to be a lot higher than a probability based on random sampling.

So I'm a statistician, and I take issue with your second computation to get the 91% probability of having the disease.

That requires the very strong assumption that your tests and how they relate to your getting a positive result are independent.

In a real test it is highly unlikely that you tested positive based on entirely random things, so a single positive test increases your posterior chance of testing positive again even if you are negative.

I get the pedagogical value, but it's important to acknowledge the implicit assumptions that you are relying on because the accuracy of your results are based on the validity of your assumptions.

Wait. Isn't the 99% test result a completely different probabilistic statement than the Bayesian percentage?

It provides an interesting contrast but why are they being compared?

Isn't the first a statement about the likelihood of a test result being correct? The second Bayesian statement is relationship of the likelihood of an individual contracting a specific disease in a particular population relative to the former result, right?

Now that I think about it there are circumstances where the test result will match the Bayesian result. Probably....

It's worth pointing out that the example given (9% chance to 91% after two tests) depends on the test being truly independent from the first test. In real life this may not be the case. For instance, if the false positive tests happen because of some genetic pattern you have, and they always test positive for you, then you're still at 9% chance even after a bunch of positive tests come back. 91% only happens if you ignore all the complexities of the real world not captured by the formulas. Just thought I'd point that out.

For those curious how Bayes theorem is applied in statistical practice, usually a model is specified, often consisting of several levels. For example, if estimating a population mean from data, you might specify a t-distribution (because you are not sure if the population is really normal, or perhaps you have outliers in your data set) with a mean, std dev, and normality parameter. For each of those, a distribution is specified for how you think the parameter could distributed. Ie, the mean might come from a normal distribution of means, the standard deviation a uniform distribution from n1 to n2, and the normality parameter from an exponential distrbution such that low degrees of freedom are more likely than high. Hence the information put into the prior is more a representation of uncertainty, than specific information. Unless you have really good reliable information to plug in.

The actual probability results from the second test have some additional dependencies. There is an assumption that the error of the test is random rather than systemic. That is, given you and the same 999 other people taking the test a second time, a random different 10 people will produce a false positive, you will get the results stated. However, if the test's inaccuracy is systemic, that is to say that it will identify the same other 10 people with a false positive, then your odds of actually having the disease is unchanged. In reality, most tests have both a random and a systemic error component and knowing those is essential to determining how meaningful a second test would be.

1:49 It usually doesn't get emphasized enough how hard it is to get a good prior. For instance, Derek's prior of just taking the incidence in the general population is probably already invalid. Why? Well, you show the symptoms of the disease, that means you are already far more likely to have the disease than joe everyman next to you.
Why is this an issue? Well, Bayes' theorem is really good at showing you the highly counterintuitive odds of something being true, you just need to know the priors. And that is a huge wild card, everything stands and falls with the prior. You can use highly biased priors to "prove" your point, you just need to convince your audience that these priors are valid (and to some extent, Derek already did this by convincingly endorsing a likely inaccurate prior).

You could argue, for instance, that human made climate change is a myth even though we have strong evidence to suggest so. You could just say, well what are the odds that us tiny puny humans can have an impact on the global scale evironment? It's infinitesimal! Just look at the size of our planet! It's HUGE! So let's just input prior p=10^-13 or something (weight of all humans / weight of the earth). I know, it's ludicrous, but try arguing against that in front of a crowd that doesn't understand the intricate details of Bayes' theorem.

That notwithstanding, Bayes is great, and it is superior to standard frequentist statistics when used correctly. However, I feel the potential to "cheat with statistics" is also far more severe with Bayes. It doesn't solve all our problems.

tldr: Always check if the prior is valid!

with regard to the end comment that touched on politics... what about bad science? There are MANY topics on which we don't like the current results, but sometimes the causes are misunderstood. Sometimes the planned fix has already been tried, but because there are too many factors in play, the results are misunderstood. Sometimes the planned fix is making things worse, but because the causes are misunderstood the fix is exacerbating the issue, but the decision is to double down on the same fix that's actually the problem...

The history of social change over the last century is one of extreme hubris, and worse extreme hubris based not on science but on pseudo-science causing countries to make sweeping changes that far more often than not make problems worse. Then on top of that, instead of reversing course, the "solutions" presented aren't questioned, but instead are deemed to have been blocked or simply not tried far enough. MOST of the biggest social problems we currently face are a combination of the unintended consequences of previous ideas and the naive lack of depth of understanding by the populace of what is still a relatively very young idea.

Instead of change for changes sake, perhaps social science ought to hone its fundamentals, and gain a stronger grasp of how the interconnections between intended solutions might work. And if the reply is that change needs to be made, and why should people suffer bad outcomes while science works when potential solutions exist: my response would be let's get some social humility, and try lots of solutions over smaller areas rather than our terrible, and seemingly accelerating, habit of sweeping national-scale "fixes", which often work for very narrow portions of the population but prove horrible for large swaths of the rest of the population.

Bayes theorem is one of the most intuitive theorems I learned so far; I mean it is the one of the first ideas you can come up with yourself, if you just think rationally about some probabilistic scenarios.
Banach-Tarski's paradox is truly counter intuitive, because no matter how hard you try rationally approaching it, your mind tells you that regardless of how you separate the points of a sphere, you cannot get two spheres that exactly match the one you started with (because you have to take out points in order to create a second sphere, which in turn modifies the first sphere). The problem that breaks this approach is the uncountable infinite supply of points.

When using any diagnostic test, it is important to "select your patient"...  Here is an extreme example: I have never left New Jersey and have no clinical signs or symptoms, therefore it would be poor patient selection to test me for malaria.  It has to do with the selectivity (identifying true positives) and specificity (identifying true negatives) of the test. Given a select population you can then determine a predictive value of the test.  A positive test for me is most likely a false positive, whereas a positive test for someone from Guinea is more likely to be a true positive. You may want to augment this Bayesian discussion with a discussion of selectivity and sensitivity.

The problem with using medical tests as an analogy to explain this theorem is that doctors increase the pre-test probability for their patients by their knowledge of diseases and their clinical suspicion. They do not just rely on how prevalent a disease is when making diagnoses. A test might incorrectly identify 1/100 random people on the street, but the test is even better than that in the hands of a physician who is only testing people with a good pre-test probability of having the disease (i.e. now it might only incorrectly identify 1/10,000, for example), and I'm concerned about the unintended consequences of telling people that one positive test is basically worthless.

This "trap" is artificially constructed by giving out misleading information. If you say that out of 1000 a single person is true positive and 10 false positive there is no trap anymore.

Also I would argue that there is still only 9% chance after the 2nd test because the result is not really random and tests are not independent. Most likely if you test false positive once because of something in your blood, you will test false positive always.

Can inspirational videos be hazardous?
Do they make us compare ourselves to others too much?
Do we look at our abilities through the eyes of others and wonder, "Why can't i do that?" or "Why can't i change my behaviour?"
That's not to say that we should stop trying, but maybe accept that we are different, with different abilities?
Different strengths and weaknesses?
Expecting different results by doing the same, over and over, is irrational and unempirical.
We need to change to have different results.
But maybe we also need to remember that change can only happen within our own limitations?
Not to say we should never challenge ourselves, or try to go further than we think we are able to..
Just be realistic and honest with ourselves?

I wish it was easier to inspire others and onesself, while staying realistic.
Not belittling the massive amount of effort it takes, to actually change.
Make it sound so much easier than it is.
"Maybe it's time to change?" or "If i can change, so can you!"?
To not compare yourself or your abilities too much to others?

It seems a better idea to use an entirely different test (if available) to make sure something like this is going on.

One of the weaknesses of modern scientific practice is that true negatives are under-reported. When an experiment yields a result that is not interesting, it is unlikely to be published (much like Bayes's theory itself I suppose).
By extension, false positives (which are interesting) are over-reported, and this skews our perception of what is. This is how we get accepted theories based on experiments that later can't be reproduced.

I think it's not just this theorem, it's probability in general. The between the first time you took the test and the second time, you still either did or did not have the disease. 9% is no more certainty than 91%.

It's like with what happened with predictions of the last American presidential election. If you say had a 40% chance of Trump winning (or 20%, or 2%, or 90%) him winning doesn't prove you wrong. Since that particular election can only happen once him winning tells you basically nothing about if you're prediction was accurate or not.

So, basically, when it comes to one off events straight probabilities are useless. There are statistical tools that can be useful, and straight probabilities can be useful for more complicated events (such as say what insurance companies do), but for most regular every day life things they're not very useful.

Your example makes the mistake of assuming that the false positives come from random noise rather than a measured quantity which is correlated with the disease. The same test may have a high repeatability but not directly measure the amount of the disease. In this case it will give a false positive every time with the same individual. Having multiple different tests will help, if they test for different 'symptoms' that are unlikely to occur together except from the actual disease.

Insanity is doing the same thing over and over and expecting a different result.
If you want to change the result you must do something different.
Truly using Bayes' theorem as a colloquialism for how you should live your life does not trap you into doing the same thing over and over. It merely states that doing the same thing probably will give you the same result. Doing something else means you are operating in the unknown as far as Bayes theorem is concerned, so you have to gather more data to get back to the same certainty of the new result (whatever it is) as you did for the previous result.
I still think math stuff like this should be kept as math. When you try to interpret it as something that it isn't you're liable to gain a view of the world that is heavily drenched in mysticism, which of course, you wouldn't want as a scientific mind that values logic and reasoning. Sure you can explore these ideas Veritasium and it very well might be useful to, but please don't take them seriously.
